[![Mississippiriver-
new-01.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Mississippiriver-

new-01.png) Mississippi River basin  
  
The **Mississippi River** is the chief river of the second-largest [drainage
system](/wiki/Drainage_system_\(geomorphology\) "Drainage system
\(geomorphology\)") on the North American continent, second only to the
[Hudson Bay](/wiki/Hudson_Bay "Hudson Bay") drainage system.[10][11] The
stream is entirely within the United States (although its [drainage
basin](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin") reaches into Canada), its source
is in northern [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") and it flows generally
south for 2,320 miles (3,730 km)[11] to the [Mississippi River
Delta](/wiki/Mississippi_River_Delta "Mississippi River Delta") in the [Gulf
of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico"). With its many
[tributaries](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary"), the Mississippi's
[watershed](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin") drains all or parts of 31
[U.S. states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") and two [Canadian
provinces](/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada "Provinces and
territories of Canada") between the [Rocky](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky
Mountains") and [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains"). The Mississippi ranks as the [fourth-
longest](/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length "List of rivers by length") and
[fifteenth-largest](/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_discharge "List of rivers by
discharge") [river](/wiki/River "River") in the world by discharge. The river
either borders or passes through the states of [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota
"Minnesota"), [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin"), [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa
"Iowa"), [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri
"Missouri"), [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"),
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee"), [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas
"Arkansas"), [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi"), and
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana").[12][13]

[Native Americans](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous
peoples of the Americas") long lived along the Mississippi River and its
tributaries. Most were [hunter-gatherers](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-
gatherer"), but some, such as the [Mound Builders](/wiki/Mound_Builders "Mound
Builders"), formed prolific agricultural societies. The arrival of Europeans
in the 16th century changed the native way of life as first explorers, then
settlers, ventured into the basin in increasing numbers.[14] The river served
first as a barrier, forming borders for [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New
Spain"), [New France](/wiki/New_France "New France"), and the early United
States, and then as a vital transportation artery and communications link. In
the 19th century, during the height of the ideology of [manifest
destiny](/wiki/Manifest_destiny "Manifest destiny"), the Mississippi and
several western tributaries, most notably the [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri_River
"Missouri River"), formed pathways for the western expansion of the United
States.

Formed from thick layers of the river's [silt](/wiki/Silt "Silt") deposits,
the [Mississippi embayment](/wiki/Mississippi_embayment "Mississippi
embayment") is one of the most fertile agricultural regions of the country,
which resulted in the river's storied
[steamboat](/wiki/Steamboats_of_the_Mississippi "Steamboats of the
Mississippi") era. During the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War
"American Civil War"), the Mississippi's capture by
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)")
forces marked a turning point towards victory due to the river's importance as
a route of trade and travel, not least to the
[Confederacy](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America"). Because of substantial growth of cities and the larger ships and
[barges](/wiki/Barge "Barge") that supplanted riverboats, the first decades of
the 20th century saw the construction of massive [engineering
works](/wiki/River_engineering "River engineering") such as
[levees](/wiki/Levee "Levee"), [locks](/wiki/Lock_\(water_navigation\) "Lock
\(water navigation\)") and [dams](/wiki/Dam "Dam"), often built in
combination.

Since modern development of the basin began, the Mississippi has also seen its
share of pollution and environmental problems – most notably large volumes of
agricultural runoff, which has led to the [Gulf of Mexico dead
zone](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico_dead_zone "Gulf of Mexico dead zone") off the
Delta. In recent years, the river has shown a steady shift towards the
[Atchafalaya River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") channel in
the Delta; a course change would be an economic disaster for the port city of
[New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans").

## Name and
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Name and significance")]

The word Mississippi itself comes from _Messipi_ , the French rendering of the
[Anishinaabe](/wiki/Ojibwe_language "Ojibwe language") (Ojibwe or Algonquin)
name for the river, _Misi-ziibi_ (Great River).

In the 18th century, the river was the primary western boundary of the young
United States, and since the country's expansion westward, the Mississippi
River has been widely considered a convenient if approximate dividing line
between the Eastern, Southern, and Midwestern United States, and the Western
United States. This is exemplified by the [Gateway Arch](/wiki/Gateway_Arch
"Gateway Arch") in St. Louis and the phrase "[Trans-Mississippi](/wiki/Trans-
Mississippi "Trans-Mississippi")" as used in the name of the [Trans-
Mississippi Exposition](/wiki/Trans-Mississippi_Exposition "Trans-Mississippi
Exposition").

It is common to qualify a regionally superlative landmark in relation to it,
such as "the [highest peak east of the Mississippi](/wiki/Mount_Mitchell
"Mount Mitchell")"[15] or "the oldest city west of the Mississippi".[16] The
[FCC](/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications
Commission") also uses it as the dividing line for [broadcast
callsigns](/wiki/Broadcast_callsign "Broadcast callsign"), which begin with W
to the east and K to the west, mixing together in [media
markets](/wiki/Media_market "Media market") along the river.

## Physical
geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Physical geography")]

The geographical setting of the Mississippi River includes considerations of
the course of the river itself, its watershed, its outflow, its prehistoric
and historic course changes, and possibilities of future course changes. The
[New Madrid Seismic Zone](/wiki/New_Madrid_Seismic_Zone "New Madrid Seismic
Zone") along the river is also noteworthy. These various basic geographical
aspects of the river in turn underlie its human history and present uses of
the waterway and its adjacent lands.

###
Divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Divisions")]

The Mississippi River can be divided into three sections: the [Upper
Mississippi](/wiki/Upper_Mississippi "Upper Mississippi"), the river from its
headwaters to the confluence with the Missouri River; the Middle Mississippi,
which is downriver from the Missouri to the Ohio River; and the [Lower
Mississippi](/wiki/Lower_Mississippi "Lower Mississippi"), which flows from
the Ohio to the Gulf of Mexico.

#### Upper
Mississippi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Upper Mississippi")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/WyalusingStateParkWisconsinRiverIntoMississippiRiver.jpg/220px-
WyalusingStateParkWisconsinRiverIntoMississippiRiver.jpg)](/wiki/File:WyalusingStateParkWisconsinRiverIntoMississippiRiver.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:WyalusingStateParkWisconsinRiverIntoMississippiRiver.jpg
"Enlarge")

Confluence of the [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin_River "Wisconsin River") and
Mississippi Rivers, viewed from [Wyalusing State
Park](/wiki/Wyalusing_State_Park "Wyalusing State Park") in Wisconsin

The Upper Mississippi runs from its headwaters to its confluence with the
Missouri River at St. Louis, Missouri. It is divided into two sections:

  1. The headwaters, 493 miles (793 km) from the source to [Saint Anthony Falls](/wiki/Saint_Anthony_Falls "Saint Anthony Falls") in [Minneapolis, Minnesota](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis"); and
  2. A navigable channel, formed by a series of man-made lakes between Minneapolis and St. Louis, Missouri, some 664 miles (1,069 km).

The source of the Upper Mississippi branch is traditionally accepted as [Lake
Itasca](/wiki/Lake_Itasca "Lake Itasca"), 1,475 feet (450 m) above sea level
in [Itasca State Park](/wiki/Itasca_State_Park "Itasca State Park") in
[Clearwater County, Minnesota](/wiki/Clearwater_County,_Minnesota "Clearwater
County, Minnesota"). The name "Itasca" was chosen to designate the "true head"
of the Mississippi River as a combination of the last four letters of the
Latin word for truth (_veritas_) and the first two letters of the Latin word
for head (_caput_).[17] However, the lake is in turn fed by a number of
smaller streams.

From its origin at [Lake Itasca](/wiki/Lake_Itasca "Lake Itasca") to [St.
Louis, Missouri](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis, Missouri"), the
waterway's flow is moderated by 43 dams. Fourteen of these dams are located
above Minneapolis in the [headwaters](/wiki/Headwater "Headwater") region and
serve multiple purposes, including power generation and recreation. The
remaining 29 dams, beginning in downtown Minneapolis, all contain locks and
were constructed to improve commercial navigation of the upper river. Taken as
a whole, these 43 dams significantly shape the geography and influence the
ecology of the upper river. Beginning just below [Saint Paul,
Minnesota](/wiki/Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "Saint Paul, Minnesota"), and
continuing throughout the upper and lower river, the Mississippi is further
controlled by thousands of [wing dikes](/wiki/Wing_Dike "Wing Dike") that
moderate the river's flow in order to maintain an open navigation channel and
prevent the river from eroding its banks.

The [head of navigation](/wiki/Head_of_navigation "Head of navigation") on the
Mississippi is the Coon Rapids Dam in [Coon Rapids,
Minnesota](/wiki/Coon_Rapids,_Minnesota "Coon Rapids, Minnesota"). Before it
was built in 1913, steamboats could occasionally go upstream as far as [Saint
Cloud, Minnesota](/wiki/Saint_Cloud,_Minnesota "Saint Cloud, Minnesota"),
depending on river conditions.

The uppermost lock and dam on the Upper Mississippi River is the Upper St.
Anthony Falls Lock and Dam in Minneapolis. Above the dam, the river's
elevation is 799 feet (244 m). Below the dam, the river's elevation is 750
feet (230 m). This 49-foot (15 m) drop is the largest of all the Mississippi
River locks and dams. The origin of the dramatic drop is a waterfall preserved
adjacent to the lock under an apron of concrete. [Saint Anthony
Falls](/wiki/Saint_Anthony_Falls "Saint Anthony Falls") is the only true
waterfall on the entire Mississippi River. The water elevation continues to
drop steeply as it passes through the gorge carved by the waterfall.

After the completion of the St. Anthony Falls Lock and Dam in 1963, the
river's head of navigation moved upstream, to the [Coon Rapids
Dam](/wiki/Coon_Rapids_Dam "Coon Rapids Dam"). However, the Locks were closed
in 2015 to control the spread of invasive [Asian
carp](/wiki/Asian_carp_in_North_America "Asian carp in North America"), making
Minneapolis once again the site of the head of navigation of the river.[18]

The Upper Mississippi has a number of natural and artificial lakes, with its
widest point being [Lake Winnibigoshish](/wiki/Lake_Winnibigoshish "Lake
Winnibigoshish"), near [Grand Rapids, Minnesota](/wiki/Grand_Rapids,_Minnesota
"Grand Rapids, Minnesota"), over 11 miles (18 km) across. [Lake
Onalaska](/wiki/Lake_Onalaska "Lake Onalaska"), created by [Lock and Dam No.
7](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._7 "Lock and Dam No. 7"), near [La Crosse,
Wisconsin](/wiki/La_Crosse,_Wisconsin "La Crosse, Wisconsin"), is more than 4
miles (6.4 km) wide. [Lake Pepin](/wiki/Lake_Pepin "Lake Pepin"), a natural
lake formed behind the delta of the [Chippewa
River](/wiki/Chippewa_River_\(Wisconsin\) "Chippewa River \(Wisconsin\)") of
Wisconsin as it enters the Upper Mississippi, is more than 2 miles (3.2 km)
wide.[19]

By the time the Upper Mississippi reaches [Saint
Paul](/wiki/Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "Saint Paul, Minnesota"), Minnesota, below
Lock and Dam No. 1, it has dropped more than half its original elevation and
is 687 feet (209 m) above sea level. From St. Paul to St. Louis, Missouri, the
river elevation falls much more slowly, and is controlled and managed as a
series of pools created by 26 locks and dams.[20]

The Upper Mississippi River is joined by the [Minnesota
River](/wiki/Minnesota_River "Minnesota River") at [Fort
Snelling](/wiki/Fort_Snelling "Fort Snelling") in the [Twin
Cities](/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul "Minneapolis–Saint Paul"); the
[St. Croix River](/wiki/St._Croix_River_\(Wisconsin-Minnesota\) "St. Croix
River \(Wisconsin-Minnesota\)") near [Prescott,
Wisconsin](/wiki/Prescott,_Wisconsin "Prescott, Wisconsin"); the [Cannon
River](/wiki/Cannon_River_\(Minnesota\) "Cannon River \(Minnesota\)") near
[Red Wing, Minnesota](/wiki/Red_Wing,_Minnesota "Red Wing, Minnesota"); the
[Zumbro River](/wiki/Zumbro_River "Zumbro River") at [Wabasha,
Minnesota](/wiki/Wabasha,_Minnesota "Wabasha, Minnesota"); the
[Black](/wiki/Black_River_\(Wisconsin\) "Black River \(Wisconsin\)"), [La
Crosse](/wiki/La_Crosse_River "La Crosse River"), and
[Root](/wiki/Root_River_\(Minnesota\) "Root River \(Minnesota\)") rivers in
[La Crosse, Wisconsin](/wiki/La_Crosse,_Wisconsin "La Crosse, Wisconsin"); the
[Wisconsin River](/wiki/Wisconsin_River "Wisconsin River") at [Prairie du
Chien, Wisconsin](/wiki/Prairie_du_Chien,_Wisconsin "Prairie du Chien,
Wisconsin"); the [Rock River](/wiki/Rock_River_\(Mississippi_River\) "Rock
River \(Mississippi River\)") at the [Quad Cities](/wiki/Quad_Cities "Quad
Cities"); the [Iowa River](/wiki/Iowa_River "Iowa River") near [Wapello,
Iowa](/wiki/Wapello,_Iowa "Wapello, Iowa"); the [Skunk
River](/wiki/Skunk_River "Skunk River") south of [Burlington,
Iowa](/wiki/Burlington,_Iowa "Burlington, Iowa"); and the [Des Moines
River](/wiki/Des_Moines_River "Des Moines River") at Keokuk, Iowa. Other major
tributaries of the Upper Mississippi include the [Crow
River](/wiki/Crow_River_\(Minnesota\) "Crow River \(Minnesota\)") in
Minnesota, the [Chippewa River](/wiki/Chippewa_River_\(Wisconsin\) "Chippewa
River \(Wisconsin\)") in Wisconsin, the [Maquoketa
River](/wiki/Maquoketa_River "Maquoketa River") and the [Wapsipinicon
River](/wiki/Wapsipinicon_River "Wapsipinicon River") in Iowa, and the
[Illinois River](/wiki/Illinois_River "Illinois River") in Illinois.

The Upper Mississippi is largely a multi-thread stream with many
[bars](/wiki/Bar_\(river_morphology\) "Bar \(river morphology\)") and islands.
From its confluence with the St. Croix River downstream to [Dubuque,
Iowa](/wiki/Dubuque,_Iowa "Dubuque, Iowa"), the river is entrenched, with high
bedrock bluffs lying on either side. The height of these bluffs decreases to
the south of Dubuque, though they are still significant through [Savanna,
Illinois](/wiki/Savanna,_Illinois "Savanna, Illinois"). This topography
contrasts strongly with the Lower Mississippi, which is a meandering river in
a broad, flat area, only rarely flowing alongside a bluff (as at [Vicksburg,
Mississippi](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg, Mississippi")).

#### Middle
Mississippi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Middle Mississippi")]

The Mississippi River is known as the Middle Mississippi from the Upper
Mississippi River's confluence with the [Missouri River](/wiki/Missouri_River
"Missouri River") at St. Louis, Missouri, for 190 miles (310 km) to its
confluence with the Ohio River at Cairo, Illinois.[21][22]

The Middle Mississippi is relatively free-flowing. From St. Louis to the Ohio
River confluence, the Middle Mississippi falls 220 feet (67 m) over 180 miles
(290 km) for an average rate of 1.2 feet per mile (23 cm/km). At its
confluence with the Ohio River, the Middle Mississippi is 315 feet (96 m)
above sea level. Apart from the Missouri and [Meramec](/wiki/Meramec_River
"Meramec River") rivers of Missouri and the [Kaskaskia
River](/wiki/Kaskaskia_River "Kaskaskia River") of Illinois, no major
tributaries enter the Middle Mississippi River.

#### Lower
Mississippi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Lower Mississippi")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Mississippi_River_-
_New_Orleans.jpg/220px-Mississippi_River_-
_New_Orleans.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_-_New_Orleans.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_-_New_Orleans.jpg "Enlarge")

Lower Mississippi River near New Orleans

The Mississippi River is called the Lower Mississippi River from its
confluence with the Ohio River to its mouth at the Gulf of Mexico, a distance
of about 1,000 miles (1,600 km). At the confluence of the Ohio and the Middle
Mississippi, the long-term mean discharge of the Ohio at Cairo, Illinois is
281,500 cubic feet per second (7,970 cubic metres per second),[23] while the
long-term mean discharge of the Mississippi at Thebes, Illinois (just upriver
from Cairo) is 208,200 cu ft/s (5,900 m3/s).[24] Thus, by volume, the main
branch of the Mississippi River system at Cairo can be considered to be the
Ohio River (and the [Allegheny River](/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River")
further upstream), rather than the Middle Mississippi.

In addition to the [Ohio River](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River"), the major
tributaries of the Lower Mississippi River are the [White
River](/wiki/White_River_\(Arkansas\) "White River \(Arkansas\)"), flowing in
at the [White River National Wildlife
Refuge](/wiki/White_River_National_Wildlife_Refuge "White River National
Wildlife Refuge") in east central Arkansas; the [Arkansas
River](/wiki/Arkansas_River "Arkansas River"), joining the Mississippi at
[Arkansas Post](/wiki/Arkansas_Post_National_Memorial "Arkansas Post National
Memorial"); the [Big Black River](/wiki/Big_Black_River_\(Mississippi\) "Big
Black River \(Mississippi\)") in Mississippi; and the [Yazoo
River](/wiki/Yazoo_River "Yazoo River"), meeting the Mississippi at
[Vicksburg, Mississippi](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg,
Mississippi"). The widest point of the Mississippi River is in the Lower
Mississippi portion where it exceeds 1 mile (1.6 km) in width in several
places.

Deliberate water diversion at the [Old River Control
Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure "Old River Control Structure") in
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") allows the [Atchafalaya
River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") in Louisiana to be a major
[distributary](/wiki/Distributary "Distributary") of the Mississippi River,
with 30% of the Mississippi flowing to the Gulf of Mexico by this route,
rather than continuing down the Mississippi's current channel past [Baton
Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge "Baton Rouge") and [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans") on a longer route to the Gulf.[25][26][27] Although the [Red
River](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_South "Red River of the South") is commonly
thought to be a tributary, it is actually not, because its water flows
separately into the Gulf of Mexico through the Atchafalaya River.

"Edit section: Watershed")]

See also: [List of drainage basins by

The Mississippi River has the world's fourth-largest [drainage
basin](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin") ("watershed" or "catchment").
The basin covers more than 1,245,000 square miles (3,220,000 km2), including
all or parts of 31[28] U.S. states and two Canadian provinces. The drainage
basin empties into the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of
Mexico"), part of the Atlantic Ocean. The total catchment of the Mississippi
River covers nearly 40% of the landmass of the continental United States. The
highest point within the watershed is also the highest point of the [Rocky
Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"), [Mount
Elbert](/wiki/Mount_Elbert "Mount Elbert") at 14,440 feet (4,400 m).[29]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/MississippiRiver_GulfMex_MODIS_2004jul-
aug.jpg/220px-MississippiRiver_GulfMex_MODIS_2004jul-
aug.jpg)](/wiki/File:MississippiRiver_GulfMex_MODIS_2004jul-aug.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MississippiRiver_GulfMex_MODIS_2004jul-aug.jpg "Enlarge")

Sequence of NASA [MODIS](/wiki/Moderate-Resolution_Imaging_Spectroradiometer
"Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer") images showing the outflow of
fresh water from the Mississippi (arrows) into the Gulf of Mexico (2004)

In the United States, the Mississippi River drains the majority of the area
between the crest of the [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky
Mountains") and the crest of the [Appalachian
Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains"), except for
various regions drained to [Hudson Bay](/wiki/Hudson_Bay "Hudson Bay") by the
[Red River of the North](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_North "Red River of the
North"); to the Atlantic Ocean by the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great
Lakes") and the [Saint Lawrence River](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_River "Saint
Lawrence River"); and to the Gulf of Mexico by the [Rio
Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande"), the [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama_River
"Alabama River") and [Tombigbee](/wiki/Tombigbee_River "Tombigbee River")
rivers, the [Chattahoochee](/wiki/Chattahoochee_River "Chattahoochee River")
and [Appalachicola](/wiki/Apalachicola_River "Apalachicola River") rivers, and
various smaller coastal waterways along the Gulf.

The Mississippi River empties into the Gulf of Mexico about 100 miles (160 km)
downstream from New Orleans. Measurements of the length of the Mississippi
from Lake Itasca to the Gulf of Mexico vary somewhat, but the [United States
Geological Survey](/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey "United States
Geological Survey")'s number is 2,320 miles (3,730 km). The retention time
from Lake Itasca to the Gulf is typically about 90 days.[30]

### Outflow[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Outflow")]

The Mississippi River discharges at an annual average rate of between 200 and
700 thousand cubic feet per second (7,000–20,000 m3/s).[31] Although it is the
fifth-largest river in the world by volume, this flow is a small fraction of
the output of [the Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_River "Amazon River"), which moves
nearly 7 million cubic feet per second (200,000 m3/s) during wet seasons. On
average, the Mississippi has only 8% the flow of the Amazon River.[32]

Fresh river water flowing from the Mississippi into the Gulf of Mexico does
not mix into the salt water immediately. The images from [NASA](/wiki/NASA
"NASA")'s [MODIS](/wiki/Moderate-Resolution_Imaging_Spectroradiometer
"Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer") (to the right) show a large
plume of fresh water, which appears as a dark ribbon against the lighter-blue
surrounding waters. These images demonstrate that the plume did not mix with
the surrounding sea water immediately. Instead, it stayed intact as it flowed
through the Gulf of Mexico, into the [Straits of
Florida](/wiki/Straits_of_Florida "Straits of Florida"), and entered the [Gulf
Stream](/wiki/Gulf_Stream "Gulf Stream"). The Mississippi River water rounded
the tip of Florida and traveled up the southeast coast to the latitude of
[Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_\(U.S._state\) "Georgia \(U.S. state\)") before
finally mixing in so thoroughly with the ocean that it could no longer be
detected by MODIS.

Before 1900, the Mississippi River transported an estimated 400 million metric
tons of [sediment](/wiki/Sediment "Sediment") per year from the interior of
the United States to coastal Louisiana and the Gulf of Mexico. During the last
two decades, this number was only 145 million metric tons per year. The
reduction in [sediment transported](/wiki/Sediment_transport "Sediment
transport") down the Mississippi River is the result of engineering
modification of the Mississippi, Missouri, and Ohio rivers and their
tributaries by dams, [meander cutoffs](/wiki/Meander_cutoff "Meander cutoff"),
river-training structures, and bank revetments and soil
[erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") control programs in the areas drained by
them.[33]

### Course
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Course changes")]

Over geologic time, the Mississippi River has experienced numerous large and
small changes to its main course, as well as additions, deletions, and other
changes among its numerous tributaries, and the lower Mississippi River has
used different pathways as its main channel to the Gulf of Mexico across the
delta region.

Through a natural process known as [avulsion](/wiki/Avulsion_\(river\)
"Avulsion \(river\)") or delta switching, the lower Mississippi River has
shifted its final course to the mouth of the Gulf of Mexico every thousand
years or so. This occurs because the deposits of silt and sediment begin to
clog its channel, raising the river's level and causing it to eventually find
a steeper, more direct route to the Gulf of Mexico. The abandoned
distributaries diminish in volume and form what are known as
[bayous](/wiki/Bayou "Bayou"). This process has, over the past 5,000 years,
caused the coastline of south Louisiana to advance toward the Gulf from 15 to
50 miles (24 to 80 km). The currently active delta lobe is called the Birdfoot
Delta, after its shape, or the [Balize
Delta](/w/index.php?title=Balize_Delta&action=edit&redlink=1 "Balize Delta
\(page does not exist\)"), after [La Balize,
Louisiana](/wiki/La_Balize,_Louisiana "La Balize, Louisiana"), the first
French settlement at the mouth of the Mississippi.

#### Prehistoric
courses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Prehistoric courses")]

The current form of the Mississippi River basin was largely shaped by the
[Laurentide Ice Sheet](/wiki/Laurentide_Ice_Sheet "Laurentide Ice Sheet") of
the [most recent](/wiki/Last_glacial_period "Last glacial period") [Ice
Age](/wiki/Ice_Age "Ice Age"). The southernmost extent of this enormous
glaciation extended well into the present-day United States and Mississippi
basin. When the ice sheet began to recede, hundreds of feet of rich sediment
were deposited, creating the flat and fertile landscape of the Mississippi
Valley. During the melt, giant glacial rivers found drainage paths into the
Mississippi watershed, creating such features as the [Minnesota
River](/wiki/Minnesota_River "Minnesota River"), [James
River](/wiki/James_River_\(Dakotas\) "James River \(Dakotas\)"), and [Milk
River](/wiki/Milk_River_\(Montana-Alberta\) "Milk River \(Montana-Alberta\)")
valleys. When the ice sheet completely retreated, many of these "temporary"
rivers found paths to [Hudson Bay](/wiki/Hudson_Bay "Hudson Bay") or the
Arctic Ocean, leaving the Mississippi Basin with many features "oversized" for
the existing rivers to have carved in the same time period.

Ice sheets during the [Illinoian Stage](/wiki/Illinoian_\(stage\) "Illinoian
\(stage\)") about 300,000 to 132,000 years before present, blocked the
Mississippi near Rock Island, Illinois, diverting it to its present channel
farther to the west, the current western border of Illinois. The [Hennepin
Canal](/wiki/Hennepin_Canal_Parkway_State_Park "Hennepin Canal Parkway State
Park") roughly follows the ancient channel of the Mississippi downstream from
Rock Island to [Hennepin, Illinois](/wiki/Hennepin,_Illinois "Hennepin,
Illinois"). South of Hennepin, to [Alton, Illinois](/wiki/Alton,_Illinois
"Alton, Illinois"), the current [Illinois River](/wiki/Illinois_River
"Illinois River") follows the ancient channel used by the Mississippi River
before the Illinoian Stage.[34][35]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Reverie_TN_08_former_MS_river_S.jpg/220px-
Reverie_TN_08_former_MS_river_S.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reverie_TN_08_former_MS_river_S.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reverie_TN_08_former_MS_river_S.jpg "Enlarge")

View along the former riverbed at the [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee
"Tennessee")/[Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas") state line near [Reverie,
Tennessee](/wiki/Reverie,_Tennessee "Reverie, Tennessee") (2007)

Timeline of outflow course changes[36]

  * c.5000 BC: The last [Ice Age](/wiki/Ice_Age "Ice Age") ended; world sea level became what it is now.
  * c.2500 BC: [Bayou Teche](/wiki/Bayou_Teche "Bayou Teche") became the main course of the Mississippi.
  * c.800 BC: The Mississippi diverted further east.
  * c.200 AD: [Bayou Lafourche](/wiki/Bayou_Lafourche "Bayou Lafourche") became the main course of the Mississippi.
  * c.1000 AD: The Mississippi's present course took over.
  * Before c.1400 AD: The [Red River of the South](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_South "Red River of the South") flowed parallel to the lower Mississippi to the sea
  * 15th century: [Turnbull's Bend](/wiki/Turnbull%27s_Bend "Turnbull's Bend") in the lower Mississippi extended so far west that it captured the Red River of the South. The Red River below the captured section became the [Atchafalaya River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River").
  * 1831: [Captain Henry M. Shreve](/wiki/Captain_Henry_M._Shreve "Captain Henry M. Shreve") dug a new short course for the Mississippi through the neck of Turnbull's Bend.
  * 1833 to November 1873: The [Great Raft](/wiki/Great_Raft "Great Raft") (a huge [logjam](/wiki/Logjam "Logjam") in the Atchafalaya River) was cleared. The Atchafalaya started to capture the Mississippi and to become its new main lower course.
  * 1963: The [Old River Control Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure "Old River Control Structure") was completed, controlling how much Mississippi water entered the Atchafalaya.
  * [Cahokia's rise and fall linked to river flooding](http://popular-archaeology.com/issue/spring-2015/article/cahokia-s-rise-and-fall-linked-to-river-flooding) (article in Popular Archaeology periodical)

#### Historic course
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Historic course changes")]

In March 1876, the Mississippi suddenly changed course near the settlement of
[Reverie, Tennessee](/wiki/Reverie,_Tennessee "Reverie, Tennessee"), leaving a
small part of [Tipton County, Tennessee](/wiki/Tipton_County,_Tennessee
"Tipton County, Tennessee"), attached to [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas")
and separated from the rest of [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee") by the
new river channel. Since this event was an [avulsion](/wiki/Avulsion_\(river\)
"Avulsion \(river\)"), rather than the effect of incremental erosion and
deposition, the state line still follows the old channel.[37] The town of
[Kaskaskia, Illinois](/wiki/Kaskaskia,_Illinois "Kaskaskia, Illinois") once
stood on a peninsula at the confluence of the Mississippi and [Kaskaskia
(Okaw) Rivers](/wiki/Kaskaskia_River "Kaskaskia River"). Founded as a French
colonial community, it later became the capital of the Illinois Territory and
was the first state capital of Illinois until 1819. Beginning in 1844,
successive flooding caused the Mississippi River to slowly encroach east. A
major flood in 1881 caused it to overtake the lower 10 miles of the Kaskaskia
River, forming a new Mississippi channel and cutting off the town from the
rest of the state. Later flooding destroyed most of the remaining town,
including the original State House. Today, the remaining 2,300 acre island and
community of 14 residents is known as an enclave of Illinois and is accessible
only from the Missouri side.[38]

### New Madrid Seismic
Zone[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: New Madrid Seismic Zone")]

The [New Madrid Seismic Zone](/wiki/New_Madrid_Seismic_Zone "New Madrid
Seismic Zone"), along the Mississippi River near [New Madrid,
Missouri](/wiki/New_Madrid,_Missouri "New Madrid, Missouri"), between Memphis
and St. Louis, is related to an [aulacogen](/wiki/Aulacogen "Aulacogen")
(failed rift) that formed at the same time as the Gulf of Mexico. This area is
still quite active seismically. [Four great earthquakes in 1811 and
1812](/wiki/1812_New_Madrid_earthquake "1812 New Madrid earthquake"),
estimated at approximately 8 on the [Richter magnitude
scale](/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale "Richter magnitude scale"), had
tremendous local effects in the then sparsely settled area, and were felt in
many other places in the midwestern and eastern U.S. These earthquakes created
[Reelfoot Lake](/wiki/Reelfoot_Lake "Reelfoot Lake") in Tennessee from the
altered landscape near the river.

## Cultural
geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Cultural geography")]

### State
boundaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: State boundaries")]

The Mississippi River runs through or along 10 states, from
[Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") to [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana
"Louisiana"), and was used to define portions of these states' borders, with
[Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin"), [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois
"Illinois"), [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"),
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee"), and [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi
"Mississippi") along the east side of the river, and [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa
"Iowa"), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), and [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas
"Arkansas") along its west side. Substantial parts of both Minnesota and
Louisiana are on either side of the river, although the Mississippi defines
part of the boundary of each of these states.

In all of these cases, the middle of the riverbed at the time the borders were
established was used as the line to define the borders between adjacent
states.[39][40] In various areas, the river has since shifted, but the state
borders have not changed, still following the former bed of the Mississippi
River as of their establishment, leaving several small isolated areas of one
state across the new river channel, contiguous with the adjacent state. Also,
due to a meander in the river, a [small part of western
Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky_Bend "Kentucky Bend") is contiguous with Tennessee,
but isolated from the rest of its state.

### Bridge
crossings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Bridge crossings")]

See also: [List of crossings of the Upper Mississippi
River](/wiki/List_of_crossings_of_the_Upper_Mississippi_River "List of
crossings of the Upper Mississippi River") and [List of crossings of the Lower
Mississippi River](/wiki/List_of_crossings_of_the_Lower_Mississippi_River
"List of crossings of the Lower Mississippi River")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Mississippi_River_from_the_Guthrie_Theater.jpg/220px-
Mississippi_River_from_the_Guthrie_Theater.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_from_the_Guthrie_Theater.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_from_the_Guthrie_Theater.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Stone Arch Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Arch_Bridge_\(Minneapolis\) "Stone Arch
Bridge \(Minneapolis\)"), the [Third Avenue
Bridge](/wiki/Third_Avenue_Bridge_\(Minneapolis\) "Third Avenue Bridge
\(Minneapolis\)") and the [Hennepin Avenue
Bridge](/wiki/Hennepin_Avenue_Bridge "Hennepin Avenue Bridge") in Minneapolis
(2004)

The road crossing highest on the Upper Mississippi is a simple steel culvert,
through which the river (locally named "Nicolet Creek") flows north from Lake
Nicolet under "Wilderness Road" to the West Arm of Lake Itasca, within [Itasca
State Park](/wiki/Itasca_State_Park "Itasca State Park").[41]

The earliest bridge across the Mississippi River was built in 1855. It spanned
the river in [Minneapolis, Minnesota](/wiki/Minneapolis,_Minnesota
"Minneapolis, Minnesota") where the current [Hennepin Avenue
Bridge](/wiki/Hennepin_Avenue_Bridge "Hennepin Avenue Bridge") is located.[42]
No highway or railroad tunnels cross under the Mississippi River.

The first railroad bridge across the Mississippi was built in 1856. It spanned
the river between the [Rock Island Arsenal](/wiki/Rock_Island_Arsenal "Rock
Island Arsenal") in [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") and Davenport, Iowa.
Steamboat captains of the day, fearful of competition from the railroads,
considered the new bridge a hazard to navigation. Two weeks after the bridge
opened, the steamboat _Effie Afton_ rammed part of the bridge, setting it on
fire. Legal proceedings ensued, with [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln
"Abraham Lincoln") defending the railroad. The lawsuit went to the [Supreme
Court of the United States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme
Court of the United States"), which ruled in favor of the railroad.[43]

Below is a general overview of selected Mississippi bridges which have notable
engineering or landmark significance, with their cities or locations. They are
sequenced from the Upper Mississippi's source to the Lower Mississippi's
mouth.

  * [Stone Arch Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Arch_Bridge_\(Minneapolis\) "Stone Arch Bridge \(Minneapolis\)") – Former [Great Northern Railway](/wiki/Great_Northern_Railway_\(U.S.\) "Great Northern Railway \(U.S.\)") (now pedestrian) bridge at [Saint Anthony Falls](/wiki/Saint_Anthony_Falls "Saint Anthony Falls") connecting downtown Minneapolis with the historic Marcy-Holmes neighborhood.
  * [I-35W Saint Anthony Falls Bridge](/wiki/I-35W_Saint_Anthony_Falls_Bridge "I-35W Saint Anthony Falls Bridge") – In Minneapolis, opened in September 2008, replacing the [I-35W Mississippi River bridge](/wiki/I-35W_Mississippi_River_bridge "I-35W Mississippi River bridge") which had collapsed catastrophically on August 1, 2007, killing 13 and injuring over 100.
  * [Eisenhower Bridge (Mississippi River)](/wiki/Eisenhower_Bridge_\(Mississippi_River\) "Eisenhower Bridge \(Mississippi River\)") – In [Red Wing, Minnesota](/wiki/Red_Wing,_Minnesota "Red Wing, Minnesota"), opened by [Dwight D. Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower") in November 1960.
  * [I-90 Mississippi River Bridge](/wiki/I-90_Mississippi_River_Bridge "I-90 Mississippi River Bridge") – Connects [La Crosse, Wisconsin](/wiki/La_Crosse,_Wisconsin "La Crosse, Wisconsin"), and [Winona County, Minnesota](/wiki/Winona_County,_Minnesota "Winona County, Minnesota"), located just south of [Lock and Dam No. 7](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._7 "Lock and Dam No. 7").
  * [Black Hawk Bridge](/wiki/Black_Hawk_Bridge "Black Hawk Bridge") – Connects [Lansing](/wiki/Lansing,_Iowa "Lansing, Iowa") in [Allamakee County, Iowa](/wiki/Allamakee_County,_Iowa "Allamakee County, Iowa") and rural [Crawford County, Wisconsin](/wiki/Crawford_County,_Wisconsin "Crawford County, Wisconsin"); locally referred to as the Lansing Bridge and documented in the [Historic American Engineering Record](/wiki/Historic_American_Buildings_Survey "Historic American Buildings Survey").

DubWisBridge051904.jpg)](/wiki/File:DubWisBridge051904.jpg)

The [Dubuque-Wisconsin Bridge](/wiki/Dubuque-Wisconsin_Bridge "Dubuque-
Wisconsin Bridge") (2004)

  * [Dubuque-Wisconsin Bridge](/wiki/Dubuque-Wisconsin_Bridge "Dubuque-Wisconsin Bridge") – Connects [Dubuque, Iowa](/wiki/Dubuque,_Iowa "Dubuque, Iowa"), and [Grant County, Wisconsin](/wiki/Grant_County,_Wisconsin "Grant County, Wisconsin").
  * [Julien Dubuque Bridge](/wiki/Julien_Dubuque_Bridge "Julien Dubuque Bridge") – Joins the cities of [Dubuque, Iowa](/wiki/Dubuque,_Iowa "Dubuque, Iowa"), and [East Dubuque, Illinois](/wiki/East_Dubuque,_Illinois "East Dubuque, Illinois"); listed in the [National Register of Historic Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places").
  * [Savanna-Sabula Bridge](/wiki/Savanna-Sabula_Bridge "Savanna-Sabula Bridge") – A [truss bridge](/wiki/Truss_bridge "Truss bridge") and causeway connecting the city of [Savanna, Illinois](/wiki/Savanna,_Illinois "Savanna, Illinois"), and the island city of [Sabula, Iowa](/wiki/Sabula,_Iowa "Sabula, Iowa"). The bridge carries [U.S. Highway 52](/wiki/U.S._Highway_52 "U.S. Highway 52") over the river, and is the terminus of both [Iowa Highway 64](/wiki/Iowa_Highway_64 "Iowa Highway 64") and [Illinois Route 64](/wiki/Illinois_Route_64 "Illinois Route 64"). Added to the [National Register of Historic Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") in 1999.
  * [Fred Schwengel Memorial Bridge](/wiki/Fred_Schwengel_Memorial_Bridge "Fred Schwengel Memorial Bridge") – A 4-lane steel girder bridge that carries [Interstate 80](/wiki/Interstate_80 "Interstate 80") and connects [LeClaire, Iowa](/wiki/LeClaire,_Iowa "LeClaire, Iowa"), and [Rapids City, Illinois](/wiki/Rapids_City,_Illinois "Rapids City, Illinois"). Completed in 1966.
  * [I-74 Bridge](/wiki/I-74_Bridge "I-74 Bridge") – Connects [Bettendorf, Iowa](/wiki/Bettendorf,_Iowa "Bettendorf, Iowa"), and [Moline, Illinois](/wiki/Moline,_Illinois "Moline, Illinois"); originally known as the _Iowa-Illinois Memorial Bridge_.
  * [Government Bridge](/wiki/Government_Bridge "Government Bridge") – Connects [Rock Island, Illinois](/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois "Rock Island, Illinois") and [Davenport, Iowa](/wiki/Davenport,_Iowa "Davenport, Iowa"), adjacent to [Lock and Dam No. 15](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._15 "Lock and Dam No. 15"); the fourth crossing in this vicinity, built in 1896.
  * [Rock Island Centennial Bridge](/wiki/Rock_Island_Centennial_Bridge "Rock Island Centennial Bridge") – Connects [Rock Island, Illinois](/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois "Rock Island, Illinois"), and [Davenport, Iowa](/wiki/Davenport,_Iowa "Davenport, Iowa"); opened in 1940.
  * [Sergeant John F. Baker, Jr. Bridge](/wiki/Sergeant_John_F._Baker,_Jr._Bridge "Sergeant John F. Baker, Jr. Bridge") – Connects [Rock Island, Illinois](/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois "Rock Island, Illinois"), and [Davenport, Iowa](/wiki/Davenport,_Iowa "Davenport, Iowa"); opened in 1973.

bridge.jpg/220px-Muscatine-ia-bridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Muscatine-ia-bridge.jpg)

Norbert F. Beckey bridge at [Muscatine](/wiki/Muscatine,_Iowa "Muscatine,
Iowa"), Iowa, with [LED](/wiki/LED "LED") lighting

  * [Norbert F. Beckey Bridge](/wiki/Norbert_F._Beckey_Bridge "Norbert F. Beckey Bridge") – Connects [Muscatine, Iowa](/wiki/Muscatine,_Iowa "Muscatine, Iowa"), and [Rock Island County, Illinois](/wiki/Rock_Island_County,_Illinois "Rock Island County, Illinois"); became first U.S. bridge to be illuminated with [light-emitting diode](/wiki/Light-emitting_diode "Light-emitting diode") (LED) lights decoratively illuminating the facade of the bridge.
  * [Great River Bridge](/wiki/Great_River_Bridge "Great River Bridge") – A [cable-stayed bridge](/wiki/Cable-stayed_bridge "Cable-stayed bridge") connecting Burlington, Iowa, to [Gulf Port, Illinois](/wiki/Gulf_Port,_Illinois "Gulf Port, Illinois").
  * [Fort Madison Toll Bridge](/wiki/Fort_Madison_Toll_Bridge "Fort Madison Toll Bridge") – Connects [Fort Madison, Iowa](/wiki/Fort_Madison,_Iowa "Fort Madison, Iowa"), and unincorporated [Niota, Illinois](/wiki/Niota,_Illinois "Niota, Illinois"); also known as the _Santa Fe Swing Span Bridge_ ; at the time of its construction the longest and heaviest electrified swing span on the Mississippi River. Listed in the [National Register of Historic Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") since 1999.
  * [Keokuk–Hamilton Bridge](/wiki/Keokuk%E2%80%93Hamilton_Bridge "Keokuk–Hamilton Bridge") – Connects [Keokuk, Iowa](/wiki/Keokuk,_Iowa "Keokuk, Iowa") and [Hamilton, Illinois](/wiki/Hamilton,_Illinois "Hamilton, Illinois"); opened in 1985 replacing an older bridge which is still in use as a railroad bridge.
  * [Bayview Bridge](/wiki/Bayview_Bridge "Bayview Bridge") – A cable-stayed bridge bringing westbound [U.S. Highway 24](/wiki/U.S._Highway_24 "U.S. Highway 24") over the river, connecting the cities of [West Quincy, Missouri](/wiki/West_Quincy,_Missouri "West Quincy, Missouri"), and [Quincy, Illinois](/wiki/Quincy,_Illinois "Quincy, Illinois").
  * [Quincy Memorial Bridge](/wiki/Quincy_Memorial_Bridge "Quincy Memorial Bridge") – Connects the cities of [West Quincy, Missouri](/wiki/West_Quincy,_Missouri "West Quincy, Missouri"), and [Quincy, Illinois](/wiki/Quincy,_Illinois "Quincy, Illinois"), carrying eastbound U.S. 24, the older of these two U.S. 24 bridges.
  * [Clark Bridge](/wiki/Clark_Bridge "Clark Bridge") – A [cable-stayed bridge](/wiki/Cable-stayed_bridge "Cable-stayed bridge") connecting [West Alton, Missouri](/wiki/West_Alton,_Missouri "West Alton, Missouri"), and [Alton, Illinois](/wiki/Alton,_Illinois "Alton, Illinois"), also known as the _Super Bridge_ as the result of an appearance on the PBS program, _[Nova](/wiki/Nova_\(TV_series\) "Nova \(TV series\)")_ ; built in 1994, carrying [U.S. Route 67](/wiki/U.S._Route_67 "U.S. Route 67") across the river. This is the northernmost river crossing in the St. Louis metropolitan area, replacing the _[Old Clark Bridge](/wiki/Old_Clark_Bridge "Old Clark Bridge")_ , a truss bridge built in 1928, named after explorer [William Clark](/wiki/William_Clark_\(explorer\) "William Clark \(explorer\)").

The [Chain of Rocks Bridge](/wiki/Chain_of_Rocks_Bridge "Chain of Rocks
Bridge") at [St. Louis, Missouri](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis,
Missouri")

  * [Chain of Rocks Bridge](/wiki/Chain_of_Rocks_Bridge "Chain of Rocks Bridge") – Located on the northern edge of St. Louis, notable for a 22-degree bend occurring at the middle of the crossing, necessary for navigation on the river; formerly used by [U.S. Route 66](/wiki/U.S._Route_66 "U.S. Route 66") to cross the Mississippi. Replaced for road traffic in 1966 by [a nearby pair of new bridges](/wiki/New_Chain_of_Rocks_Bridge "New Chain of Rocks Bridge"); now a pedestrian bridge.
  * [Eads Bridge](/wiki/Eads_Bridge "Eads Bridge") – A combined road and railway bridge, connecting St. Louis and [East St. Louis, Illinois](/wiki/East_St._Louis,_Illinois "East St. Louis, Illinois"). When completed in 1874, it was the longest arch bridge in the world, with an overall length of 6,442 feet (1,964 m). The three ribbed steel arch spans were considered daring, as was the use of steel as a primary structural material; it was the first such use of true steel in a major bridge project.
  * [Chester Bridge](/wiki/Chester_Bridge "Chester Bridge") – A [truss bridge](/wiki/Truss_bridge "Truss bridge") connecting [Route 51](/wiki/Route_51_\(Missouri\) "Route 51 \(Missouri\)") in Missouri with [Illinois Route 150](/wiki/Illinois_Route_150 "Illinois Route 150"), between [Perryville, Missouri](/wiki/Perryville,_Missouri "Perryville, Missouri"), and [Chester, Illinois](/wiki/Chester,_Illinois "Chester, Illinois"). The bridge can be seen in the beginning of the 1967 film _[In the Heat of the Night](/wiki/In_the_Heat_of_the_Night_\(film\) "In the Heat of the Night \(film\)")_. In the 1940s, the main span was destroyed by a [tornado](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado").
  * [Bill Emerson Memorial Bridge](/wiki/Bill_Emerson_Memorial_Bridge "Bill Emerson Memorial Bridge")—Connecting [Cape Girardeau, Missouri](/wiki/Cape_Girardeau,_Missouri "Cape Girardeau, Missouri") and [East Cape Girardeau, Illinois](/wiki/East_Cape_Girardeau,_Illinois "East Cape Girardeau, Illinois"), completed in 2003 and illuminated by 140 lights.
  * [Caruthersville Bridge](/wiki/Caruthersville_Bridge "Caruthersville Bridge") – A single tower cantilever bridge carrying [Interstate 155](/wiki/Interstate_155_\(Missouri%E2%80%93Tennessee\) "Interstate 155 \(Missouri–Tennessee\)") and [U.S. Route 412](/wiki/U.S._Route_412 "U.S. Route 412") across the Mississippi River between [Caruthersville, Missouri](/wiki/Caruthersville,_Missouri "Caruthersville, Missouri") and [Dyersburg, Tennessee](/wiki/Dyersburg,_Tennessee "Dyersburg, Tennessee").

  * [Hernando de Soto Bridge](/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto_Bridge "Hernando de Soto Bridge") – A [through arch bridge](/wiki/Through_arch_bridge "Through arch bridge") carrying [Interstate 40](/wiki/Interstate_40 "Interstate 40") across the Mississippi between [West Memphis, Arkansas](/wiki/West_Memphis,_Arkansas "West Memphis, Arkansas"), and [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee").
  * [Harahan Bridge](/wiki/Harahan_Bridge "Harahan Bridge") – A [cantilevered](/wiki/Cantilever_bridge "Cantilever bridge") [through truss bridge](/wiki/Truss_bridge "Truss bridge"), carrying two rail lines of the [Union Pacific Railroad](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad "Union Pacific Railroad") across the river between [West Memphis, Arkansas](/wiki/West_Memphis,_Arkansas "West Memphis, Arkansas"), and [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee").
  * [Frisco Bridge](/wiki/Frisco_Bridge "Frisco Bridge") – A [cantilevered](/wiki/Cantilever_bridge "Cantilever bridge") [through truss bridge](/wiki/Truss_bridge "Truss bridge"), carrying a rail line across the river between [West Memphis, Arkansas](/wiki/West_Memphis,_Arkansas "West Memphis, Arkansas"), and [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"), previously known as the _Memphis Bridge_. When it opened on May 12, 1892, it was the first crossing of the Lower Mississippi and the longest span in the U.S. Listed as a [Historic Civil Engineering Landmark](/wiki/List_of_historic_civil_engineering_landmarks "List of historic civil engineering landmarks").
  * [Memphis & Arkansas Bridge](/wiki/Memphis_%26_Arkansas_Bridge "Memphis & Arkansas Bridge") – A [cantilevered](/wiki/Cantilever_bridge "Cantilever bridge") [through truss bridge](/wiki/Truss_bridge "Truss bridge"), carrying [Interstate 55](/wiki/Interstate_55 "Interstate 55") between Memphis and West Memphis; listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

  * [Crescent City Connection](/wiki/Crescent_City_Connection "Crescent City Connection") – Connects the east and west banks of [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"), Louisiana; the fifth-longest [cantilever bridge](/wiki/Cantilever_bridge "Cantilever bridge") in the world.

## Navigation and flood
control[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Navigation and flood control")]

Main article: [List of locks and dams of the Upper Mississippi
River](/wiki/List_of_locks_and_dams_of_the_Upper_Mississippi_River "List of
locks and dams of the Upper Mississippi River")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/20040711181620_Mississippi_Memphis_Ausschnitt.jpg/220px-20040711181620_Mississippi_Memphis_Ausschnitt.jpg)](/wiki/File:20040711181620_Mississippi_Memphis_Ausschnitt.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:20040711181620_Mississippi_Memphis_Ausschnitt.jpg "Enlarge")

Towboat and barges at [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis,
Tennessee")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Mississippi_ship_navigation.png/220px-
Mississippi_ship_navigation.png)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_ship_navigation.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_ship_navigation.png "Enlarge")

Ships on the lower part of the Mississippi

A clear channel is needed for the [barges](/wiki/Barge "Barge") and other
vessels that make the [main stem](/wiki/Main_stem "Main stem") Mississippi one
of the great commercial [waterways](/wiki/Waterway "Waterway") of the world.
The task of maintaining a navigation channel is the responsibility of the
[United States Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "United States Army
Corps of Engineers"), which was established in 1802.[44] Earlier projects
began as early as 1829 to remove snags, close off secondary channels and
excavate rocks and [sandbars](/wiki/Shoal "Shoal").

Steamboats entered trade in the 1820s, so the period 1830–1850 became the
golden age of steamboats. As there were few roads or rails in the lands of the
Louisiana Purchase, river traffic was an ideal solution. Cotton, timber and
food came down the river, as did Appalachian coal. The port of New Orleans
boomed as it was the trans-shipment point to deep sea ocean vessels. As a
result, the image of the twin stacked, wedding cake Mississippi steamer
entered into American mythology. Steamers worked the entire route from the
trickles of Montana, to the Ohio River; down the Missouri and Tennessee, to
the main channel of the Mississippi. Only with the arrival of the railroads in
the 1880s did steamboat traffic diminish. Steamboats remained a feature until
the 1920s. Most have been superseded by pusher tugs. A few survive as
icons—the [Delta Queen](/wiki/Delta_Queen "Delta Queen") and the [River
Queen](/wiki/River_Queen_\(steamboat\) "River Queen \(steamboat\)") for
instance.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ship_on_lower_Mississippi.jpeg/220px-
Ship_on_lower_Mississippi.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Ship_on_lower_Mississippi.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Ship_on_lower_Mississippi.jpeg "Enlarge")

Oil tanker on the Lower Mississippi near the Port of New Orleans

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Lower_Mississippi_River_barge.png/220px-
Lower_Mississippi_River_barge.png)](/wiki/File:Lower_Mississippi_River_barge.png)

[](/wiki/File:Lower_Mississippi_River_barge.png "Enlarge")

Barge on the Lower Mississippi River

A series of 29 [locks](/wiki/Lock_\(water_transport\) "Lock \(water
transport\)") and dams on the upper Mississippi, most of which were built in
the 1930s, is designed primarily to maintain a 9-foot-deep (2.7 m) channel for
commercial barge traffic.[45][46] The lakes formed are also used for
recreational boating and fishing. The dams make the river deeper and wider but
do not stop it. No flood control is intended. During periods of high flow, the
gates, some of which are submersible, are completely opened and the dams
simply cease to function. Below St. Louis, the Mississippi is relatively free-
flowing, although it is constrained by numerous levees and directed by
numerous [wing dams](/wiki/Wing_dam "Wing dam").

On the lower Mississippi, from [Baton Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge,_Louisiana
"Baton Rouge, Louisiana") to the mouth of the Mississippi, the navigation
depth is 45 feet (14 m), allowing container ships and cruise ships to dock at
the [Port of New Orleans](/wiki/Port_of_New_Orleans "Port of New Orleans") and
bulk cargo ships shorter than 150-foot (46 m) air draft that fit under the
[Huey P. Long Bridge](/wiki/Huey_P._Long_Bridge_\(Jefferson_Parish\) "Huey P.
Long Bridge \(Jefferson Parish\)") to traverse the Mississippi to Baton
Rouge.[47] There is a [feasibility study](/wiki/Feasibility_study "Feasibility
study") to dredge this portion of the river to 50 feet (15 m) to allow [New
Panamax](/wiki/New_Panamax "New Panamax") ship depths.[48]

### 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 19th century")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Lock_and_Dam_11.jpg/220px-
Lock_and_Dam_11.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lock_and_Dam_11.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lock_and_Dam_11.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lock and Dam No. 11](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._11 "Lock and Dam No. 11"), north
of Dubuque, Iowa (2007)

In 1829, there were surveys of the two major obstacles on the upper
Mississippi, the [Des Moines Rapids](/wiki/Des_Moines_Rapids "Des Moines
Rapids") and the [Rock Island
Rapids](/w/index.php?title=Rock_Island_Rapids&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rock
Island Rapids \(page does not exist\)"), where the river was shallow and the
riverbed was rock. The Des Moines Rapids were about 11 miles (18 km) long and
just above the mouth of the [Des Moines River](/wiki/Des_Moines_River "Des
Moines River") at Keokuk, Iowa. The Rock Island Rapids were between [Rock
Island](/wiki/Rock_Island,_Illinois "Rock Island, Illinois") and [Moline,
Illinois](/wiki/Moline,_Illinois "Moline, Illinois"). Both rapids were
considered virtually impassable.

In 1848, the [Illinois and Michigan Canal](/wiki/Illinois_and_Michigan_Canal
"Illinois and Michigan Canal") was built to connect the Mississippi River to
[Lake Michigan](/wiki/Lake_Michigan "Lake Michigan") via the Illinois River
near [Peru, Illinois](/wiki/Peru,_Illinois "Peru, Illinois"). The canal
allowed shipping between these important waterways. In 1900, the canal was
replaced by the [Chicago Sanitary and Ship
Canal](/wiki/Chicago_Sanitary_and_Ship_Canal "Chicago Sanitary and Ship
Canal"). The second canal, in addition to shipping, also allowed Chicago to
address specific health issues ([typhoid fever](/wiki/Typhoid_fever "Typhoid
fever"), [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") and other waterborne diseases) by
sending its waste down the Illinois and Mississippi river systems rather than
polluting its water source of Lake Michigan.

The Corps of Engineers recommended the excavation of a 5-foot-deep (1.5 m)
channel at the Des Moines Rapids, but work did not begin until after
Lieutenant [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee") endorsed the
project in 1837. The Corps later also began excavating the Rock Island Rapids.
By 1866, it had become evident that excavation was impractical, and it was
decided to build a canal around the Des Moines Rapids. The canal opened in
1877, but the Rock Island Rapids remained an obstacle. In 1878, Congress
authorized the Corps to establish a 4.5-foot-deep (1.4 m) channel to be
obtained by building wing dams which direct the river to a narrow channel
causing it to cut a deeper channel, by closing secondary channels and by
dredging. The channel project was complete when the Moline Lock, which
bypassed the Rock Island Rapids, opened in 1907.

To improve navigation between St. Paul, Minnesota, and [Prairie du Chien,
Wisconsin](/wiki/Prairie_du_Chien,_Wisconsin "Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin"),
the Corps constructed several dams on lakes in the headwaters area, including
[Lake Winnibigoshish](/wiki/Lake_Winnibigoshish "Lake Winnibigoshish") and
[Lake Pokegama](/wiki/Pokegama_Dam "Pokegama Dam"). The dams, which were built
beginning in the 1880s, stored spring run-off which was released during low
water to help maintain channel depth.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_2.jpg/220px-
Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lock and Dam No. 2](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._2 "Lock and Dam No. 2"), near
[Hastings, Minnesota](/wiki/Hastings,_Minnesota "Hastings, Minnesota") (2007)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_15.jpg/220px-
Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_15.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_15.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_Lock_and_Dam_number_15.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lock and Dam No. 15](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._15 "Lock and Dam No. 15"), is the

### 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: 20th century")]

In 1907, Congress authorized a 6-foot-deep (1.8 m) channel project on the
Mississippi, which was not complete when it was abandoned in the late 1920s in
favor of the 9-foot-deep (2.7 m) channel project.

In 1913, construction was complete on [Lock and Dam No.
19](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._19 "Lock and Dam No. 19") at [Keokuk,
Iowa](/wiki/Keokuk,_Iowa "Keokuk, Iowa"), the first dam below St. Anthony
Falls. Built by a private power company ([Union Electric
Company](/wiki/Union_Electric_Company "Union Electric Company") of St. Louis)
to generate electricity (originally for [streetcars in St.
Louis](/wiki/Streetcars_in_St._Louis "Streetcars in St. Louis")), the Keokuk
dam was one of the largest [hydro-electric](/wiki/Hydro-electric "Hydro-
electric") plants in the world at the time. The dam also eliminated the Des
Moines Rapids. [Lock and Dam No.
1](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._1,_Mississippi_River "Lock and Dam No. 1,
Mississippi River") was completed in Minneapolis, Minnesota in 1917. [Lock and
Dam No. 2](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._2 "Lock and Dam No. 2"), near [Hastings,
Minnesota](/wiki/Hastings,_Minnesota "Hastings, Minnesota"), was completed in
1930.

Before the [Great Mississippi Flood of
1927](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_Flood_of_1927 "Great Mississippi Flood of
1927"), the Corps's primary strategy was to close off as many side channels as
possible to increase the flow in the main river. It was thought that the
river's [velocity](/wiki/Velocity "Velocity") would scour off bottom
[sediments](/wiki/Sediment "Sediment"), deepening the river and decreasing the
possibility of flooding. The 1927 flood proved this to be so wrong that
communities threatened by the flood began to create their own levee breaks to
relieve the force of the rising river.

The Rivers and Harbors Act of 1930 authorized the 9-foot (2.7 m) channel
project, which called for a navigation channel 9 feet (2.7 m) feet deep and
400 feet (120 m) wide to accommodate multiple-barge tows.[49][50] This was
achieved by a series of locks and dams, and by dredging. Twenty-three new
locks and dams were built on the upper Mississippi in the 1930s in addition to
the three already in existence.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Geomorphology_of_Old_River.jpg/220px-
Geomorphology_of_Old_River.jpg)](/wiki/File:Geomorphology_of_Old_River.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Geomorphology_of_Old_River.jpg "Enlarge")

Formation of the Atchafalaya River and construction of the Old River Control
Structure.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Mississippi_River_flow.gif/170px-
Mississippi_River_flow.gif)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_flow.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_flow.gif "Enlarge")

[Project design flood](/wiki/Project_design_flood "Project design flood") flow
capacity for the Mississippi river in thousands of cubic feet per second.[51]

Until the 1950s, there was no dam below Lock and Dam 26 at Alton, Illinois.
[Chain of Rocks Lock](/wiki/Chain_of_Rocks_Lock "Chain of Rocks Lock") (Lock
and Dam No. 27), which consists of a low-water dam and an 8.4-mile-long (13.5
km) canal, was added in 1953, just below the confluence with the Missouri
River, primarily to bypass a series of rock ledges at St. Louis. It also
serves to protect the St. Louis city water intakes during times of low water.

U.S. government scientists determined in the 1950s that the Mississippi River
was starting to switch to the Atchafalaya River channel because of its much
steeper path to the Gulf of Mexico. Eventually the Atchafalaya River would
capture the Mississippi River and become its main channel to the Gulf of
Mexico, leaving New Orleans on a side channel. As a result, the [U.S.
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") authorized a
project called the [Old River Control
Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure "Old River Control Structure"),
which has prevented the Mississippi River from leaving its current channel
that drains into the Gulf via New Orleans.[52]

Because the large scale of high-energy water flow threatened to damage the
structure, an auxiliary flow control station was built adjacent to the
standing control station. This $300 million project was completed in 1986 by
the Corps of Engineers. Beginning in the 1970s, the Corps applied
[hydrological transport models](/wiki/Hydrological_transport_model
"Hydrological transport model") to analyze flood flow and water quality of the
Mississippi. Dam 26 at Alton, Illinois, which had structural problems, was
replaced by the Mel Price Lock and Dam in 1990. The original Lock and Dam 26
was demolished.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Dam_-27.JPG/170px-
Dam_-27.JPG)](/wiki/File:Dam_-27.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Dam_-27.JPG "Enlarge")

A low-water dam deepens the pool above the [Chain of Rocks
Lock](/wiki/Chain_of_Rocks_Lock "Chain of Rocks Lock") near St. Louis (2006)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Army_mil-2008-07-17-085659.jpg/220px-
Army_mil-2008-07-17-085659.jpg)](/wiki/File:Army_mil-2008-07-17-085659.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Army_mil-2008-07-17-085659.jpg "Enlarge")
