### 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: 21st century")]

The Corps now actively creates and maintains spillways and floodways to divert
periodic water surges into backwater channels and lakes, as well as route part
of the Mississippi's flow into the [Atchafalaya Basin](/wiki/Atchafalaya_Basin
"Atchafalaya Basin") and from there to the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico"), bypassing [Baton
Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge "Baton Rouge") and [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans"). The main structures are the [Birds Point-New Madrid
Floodway](/wiki/Birds_Point-New_Madrid_Floodway "Birds Point-New Madrid
Floodway") in Missouri; the [Old River Control
Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure "Old River Control Structure")
and the [Morganza Spillway](/wiki/Morganza_Spillway "Morganza Spillway") in
Louisiana, which direct excess water down the west and east sides
(respectively) of the [Atchafalaya River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya
River"); and the [Bonnet Carré Spillway](/wiki/Bonnet_Carr%C3%A9_Spillway
"Bonnet Carré Spillway"), also in Louisiana, which directs floodwaters to
[Lake Pontchartrain](/wiki/Lake_Pontchartrain "Lake Pontchartrain") (see
diagram). Some experts blame [urban sprawl](/wiki/Urban_sprawl "Urban sprawl")
for increases in both the risk and frequency of flooding on the Mississippi
River.[53]

Some of the pre-1927 strategy is still in use today, with the Corps actively
cutting the necks of [horseshoe bends](/wiki/Meander "Meander"), allowing the
water to move faster and reducing flood heights.[54]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: History")]

### Native
Americans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Native Americans")]

Main articles: [Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period "Woodland period"),
[Hopewell tradition](/wiki/Hopewell_tradition "Hopewell tradition"), and
[Mississippian culture](/wiki/Mississippian_culture "Mississippian culture")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Monks_Mound_in_July.JPG/220px-
Monks_Mound_in_July.JPG)](/wiki/File:Monks_Mound_in_July.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Monks_Mound_in_July.JPG "Enlarge")

[Monks Mound](/wiki/Monks_Mound "Monks Mound"), a [platform
mound](/wiki/Platform_mound "Platform mound") at the site of the
[Mississippian](/wiki/Mississippian_culture "Mississippian culture") city of
[Cahokia](/wiki/Cahokia "Cahokia").

The area of the Mississippi River basin was first
[settled](/wiki/Prehistoric_migration_and_settlement_of_the_Americas_from_Asia
"Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia") by [hunting
and gathering](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer") [Native American
peoples](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the
United States") and is considered one of the few independent centers of [plant
domestication](/wiki/Domestication_of_plants "Domestication of plants") in
human history.[55] Evidence of early [cultivation](/wiki/Plant_cultivation
"Plant cultivation") of [sunflower](/wiki/Helianthus_annuus "Helianthus
annuus"), a [goosefoot](/wiki/Chenopodium_berlandieri "Chenopodium
berlandieri"), a [marsh elder](/wiki/Iva_annua "Iva annua") and an indigenous
[squash](/wiki/Squash_\(plant\) "Squash \(plant\)") dates to the [4th
millennium BCE](/wiki/4th_millennium_BCE "4th millennium BCE"). The lifestyle
gradually became more settled after around 1000 BCE during what is now called
the [Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period "Woodland period"), with
increasing evidence of shelter construction,
[pottery](/wiki/Ceramics_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Ceramics of
indigenous peoples of the Americas"), [weaving](/wiki/Weaving "Weaving") and
other practices. A network of trade routes referred to as the [Hopewell
interaction sphere](/wiki/Hopewell_tradition "Hopewell tradition") was active
along the waterways between about 200 and 500 CE, spreading common cultural
practices over the entire area between the Gulf of Mexico and the Great Lakes.
A period of more isolated communities followed, and agriculture introduced
from [Mesoamerica](/wiki/Mesoamerica "Mesoamerica") based on the [Three
Sisters](/wiki/Three_Sisters_\(agriculture\) "Three Sisters \(agriculture\)")
(maize, [beans](/wiki/Beans "Beans") and squash) gradually came to dominate.
After around 800 CE there arose an advanced agricultural society today
referred to as the [Mississippian culture](/wiki/Mississippian_culture
"Mississippian culture"), with evidence of highly
[stratified](/wiki/Social_stratification "Social stratification")
[complex](/wiki/Complex_society "Complex society") [chiefdoms](/wiki/Chiefdom
"Chiefdom") and large [population centers](/wiki/Human_settlement "Human
settlement"). The most prominent of these, now called [Cahokia](/wiki/Cahokia
"Cahokia"), was occupied between about 600 and 1400 CE[56] and at its peak
numbered between 8,000 and 40,000 inhabitants, larger than London, England of
that time. At the time of first contact with Europeans, Cahokia and many other
Mississippian cities had dispersed, and [archaeological](/wiki/Archaeology
"Archaeology") finds attest to increased social stress.[57][58][59]

Modern American Indian nations inhabiting the Mississippi basin include
[Cheyenne](/wiki/Cheyenne "Cheyenne"), [Sioux](/wiki/Sioux "Sioux"),
[Ojibwe](/wiki/Ojibwe "Ojibwe"), [Potawatomi](/wiki/Potawatomi "Potawatomi"),
[Ho-Chunk](/wiki/Ho-Chunk "Ho-Chunk"), [Fox](/wiki/Fox_\(tribe\) "Fox
\(tribe\)"), [Kickapoo](/wiki/Kickapoo_people "Kickapoo people"),
[Tamaroa](/wiki/Tamaroa_\(tribe\) "Tamaroa \(tribe\)"),
[Moingwena](/wiki/Moingwena "Moingwena"), [Quapaw](/wiki/Quapaw "Quapaw") and
[Chickasaw](/wiki/Chickasaw "Chickasaw").

The word _Mississippi_ itself comes from _Messipi_ , the French rendering of
the [Anishinaabe](/wiki/Ojibwe_language "Ojibwe language") (Ojibwe or
Algonquin) name for the river, _Misi-ziibi_ (Great River).[60][61] The
[Ojibwe](/wiki/Ojibwe "Ojibwe") called Lake Itasca _Omashkoozo-zaaga 'igan_
(Elk Lake) and the river flowing out of it _Omashkoozo-ziibi_ (Elk River).
After flowing into [Lake Bemidji](/wiki/Lake_Bemidji "Lake Bemidji"), the
Ojibwe called the river _Bemijigamaag-ziibi_ (River from the Traversing Lake).
After flowing into [Cass Lake](/wiki/Cass_Lake_\(Minnesota\) "Cass Lake
\(Minnesota\)"), the name of the river changes to _Gaa-miskwaawaakokaag-ziibi_
(Red Cedar River) and then out of [Lake
Winnibigoshish](/wiki/Lake_Winnibigoshish "Lake Winnibigoshish") as
_Wiinibiigoonzhish-ziibi_ (Miserable Wretched Dirty Water River), _Gichi-
ziibi_ (Big River) after the confluence with the [Leech Lake
River](/wiki/Leech_Lake_River "Leech Lake River"), then finally as _Misi-
ziibi_ (Great River) after the confluence with the [Crow Wing
River](/wiki/Crow_Wing_River "Crow Wing River").[62] After the expeditions by
[Giacomo Beltrami](/wiki/Giacomo_Beltrami "Giacomo Beltrami") and [Henry
Schoolcraft](/wiki/Henry_Schoolcraft "Henry Schoolcraft"), the longest stream
above the juncture of the Crow Wing River and _Gichi-ziibi_ was named
"Mississippi River". The [Mississippi River Band of Chippewa
Indians](/wiki/Mississippi_River_Band_of_Chippewa_Indians "Mississippi River
Band of Chippewa Indians"), known as the _Gichi-ziibiwininiwag_ , are named
after the stretch of the Mississippi River known as the _Gichi-ziibi_. The
[Cheyenne](/wiki/Cheyenne "Cheyenne"), one of the earliest inhabitants of the
upper Mississippi River, called it the _Máʼxe-éʼometaaʼe_ (Big Greasy River)
in the [Cheyenne language](/wiki/Cheyenne_language "Cheyenne language"). The
[Arapaho](/wiki/Arapaho_language "Arapaho language") name for the river is
_Beesniicíe_.[63] The [Pawnee](/wiki/Pawnee_language "Pawnee language") name
is _Kickaátit_.[64]

The Mississippi was spelled Mississipi or Missisipi during French Louisiana
and was also known as the Rivière Saint-Louis.[65][66][67]

### European
exploration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: European exploration")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Discovery_of_the_Mississippi.jpg/220px-
Discovery_of_the_Mississippi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Discovery_of_the_Mississippi.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Discovery_of_the_Mississippi.jpg "Enlarge")

_Discovery of the Mississippi by De Soto A.D. 1541_ by [William Henry
Powell](/wiki/William_Henry_Powell "William Henry Powell") depicts [Hernando
De Soto](/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto "Hernando de Soto") and Spanish
[Conquistadores](/wiki/Conquistadores "Conquistadores") seeing the Mississippi
River for the first time.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Marquette_and_jolliet_map_1681.jpg/170px-
Marquette_and_jolliet_map_1681.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marquette_and_jolliet_map_1681.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marquette_and_jolliet_map_1681.jpg "Enlarge")

Ca. 1681 map of [Marquette](/wiki/Jacques_Marquette "Jacques Marquette") and
[Jolliet](/wiki/Louis_Jolliet "Louis Jolliet")'s 1673 expedition.

On May 8, 1541, Spanish explorer [Hernando de Soto](/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto
"Hernando de Soto") became the first recorded European to reach the
Mississippi River, which he called _Río del Espíritu Santo_ ("River of the
Holy Spirit"), in the area of what is now Mississippi. In Spanish, the river
is called _Río Mississippi_.[68]

French explorers [Louis Jolliet](/wiki/Louis_Jolliet "Louis Jolliet") and
[Jacques Marquette](/wiki/Jacques_Marquette "Jacques Marquette") began
exploring the Mississippi in the 17th century. Marquette traveled with a
[Sioux](/wiki/Sioux "Sioux") Indian who named it _Ne Tongo_ ("Big river" in
[Sioux language](/wiki/Sioux_language "Sioux language")) in 1673. Marquette
proposed calling it the _River of the[Immaculate
Conception](/wiki/Immaculate_Conception "Immaculate Conception")_.

When [Louis Jolliet](/wiki/Louis_Jolliet "Louis Jolliet") explored the
Mississippi Valley in the 17th century, natives guided him to a quicker way to
return to French Canada via the Illinois River. When he found the [Chicago
Portage](/wiki/Chicago_Portage "Chicago Portage"), he remarked that a canal of
"only half a [league](/wiki/League_\(unit\) "League \(unit\)")" (less than 2
miles (3.2 km), 3 km) would join the Mississippi and the Great Lakes.[69] In
1848, the [continental divide](/wiki/Continental_divide "Continental divide")
separating the waters of the Great Lakes and the Mississippi Valley was
breached by the [Illinois and Michigan
canal](/wiki/Illinois_and_Michigan_canal "Illinois and Michigan canal") via
the [Chicago River](/wiki/Chicago_River "Chicago River").[70] This both
accelerated the development, and forever changed the ecology of the
Mississippi Valley and the Great Lakes.

In 1682, [René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La
Salle](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9-Robert_Cavelier,_Sieur_de_La_Salle "René-Robert
Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle") and [Henri de Tonti](/wiki/Henri_de_Tonti "Henri
de Tonti") claimed the entire Mississippi River Valley for France, calling the
river _Colbert River_ after [Jean-Baptiste Colbert](/wiki/Jean-
Baptiste_Colbert "Jean-Baptiste Colbert") and the region _[La
Louisiane](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New France\)")_ , for
[King Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France"). On March 2,
1699, [Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville](/wiki/Pierre_Le_Moyne_d%27Iberville
"Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville") rediscovered the mouth of the Mississippi,
following the death of La Salle.[71] The French built the small fort of [La
Balise](/wiki/La_Balize,_Louisiana "La Balize, Louisiana") there to control
passage.[72]

In 1718, about 100 miles (160 km) upriver, New Orleans was established along
the river crescent by [Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville](/wiki/Jean-
Baptiste_Le_Moyne,_Sieur_de_Bienville "Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de
Bienville"), with construction patterned after the 1711 resettlement on Mobile
Bay of [Mobile](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama "Mobile, Alabama"), the capital of
French Louisiana at the time.

###
Colonization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Colonization")]

See also: [Flood of 1851](/wiki/Flood_of_1851 "Flood of 1851")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/A_Home_on_the_Mississippi.png/220px-
A_Home_on_the_Mississippi.png)](/wiki/File:A_Home_on_the_Mississippi.png)

[](/wiki/File:A_Home_on_the_Mississippi.png "Enlarge")

_[A Home on the Mississippi](/wiki/A_Home_on_the_Mississippi "A Home on the
Mississippi")_ (1871)

Following [Britain's victory in the Seven Years
War](/wiki/Great_Britain_in_the_Seven_Years_War "Great Britain in the Seven
Years War") the Mississippi became the border between the British and Spanish
Empires. The [Treaty of Paris (1763)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1763\) "Treaty
of Paris \(1763\)") gave [Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain
"Kingdom of Great Britain") rights to all land east of the Mississippi and
Spain rights to land west of the Mississippi. Spain also ceded
[Florida](/wiki/Spanish_Florida "Spanish Florida") to Britain to regain
[Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), which the British occupied during the war. Britain
then divided the territory into [East](/wiki/East_Florida "East Florida") and
[West Florida](/wiki/West_Florida "West Florida").

Article 8 of the [Treaty of Paris (1783)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\)
"Treaty of Paris \(1783\)") states, "The navigation of the river Mississippi,
from its source to the ocean, shall forever remain free and open to the
subjects of Great Britain and the citizens of the United States". With this
treaty, which ended the [American Revolutionary
War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), Britain
also ceded West Florida back to Spain to regain [the
Bahamas](/wiki/The_Bahamas "The Bahamas"), which Spain had occupied during the
war. In 1800, under duress from Napoleon of France, Spain ceded an undefined
portion of West Florida to France. When France then sold the Louisiana
Territory to the U.S. in 1803, a dispute arose again between Spain and the
U.S. on which parts of West Florida exactly had Spain ceded to France, which
would in turn decide which parts of West Florida were now U.S. property versus
Spanish property. These aspirations ended when Spain was pressured into
signing [Pinckney's Treaty](/wiki/Pinckney%27s_Treaty "Pinckney's Treaty") in
1795.

France reacquired 'Louisiana' from Spain in the secret [Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/Third_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso") in 1800. The United States then secured effective control of the
river when it bought the Louisiana Territory from France in the [Louisiana
Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana Purchase") of 1803. The last
serious European challenge to U.S. control of the river came at the conclusion
of [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812") when British forces mounted
an attack on [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") – the attack [was
repulsed](/wiki/Battle_of_New_Orleans "Battle of New Orleans") by an American
army under the command of General [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson
"Andrew Jackson").

In the [Treaty of 1818](/wiki/Treaty_of_1818 "Treaty of 1818"), the U.S. and
Great Britain agreed to fix the border running from the [Lake of the
Woods](/wiki/Lake_of_the_Woods "Lake of the Woods") to the [Rocky
Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains") along the [49th parallel
north](/wiki/49th_parallel_north "49th parallel north"). In effect, the U.S.
ceded the northwestern extremity of the Mississippi basin to the British in
exchange for the southern portion of the [Red
River](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_North "Red River of the North") basin.

So many settlers traveled westward through the Mississippi river basin, as
well as settled in it, that Zadok Cramer wrote a guide book called _[The
Navigator](/wiki/The_Navigator_\(1801_guide_book\) "The Navigator \(1801 guide
book\)")_ , detailing the features and dangers and navigable waterways of the
area. It was so popular that he updated and expanded it through 12 editions
over a period of 25 years.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Mississippi_River-
sand_bars.jpg/220px-Mississippi_River-
sand_bars.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River-sand_bars.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River-sand_bars.jpg "Enlarge")

Shifting [sand bars](/wiki/Shoal "Shoal") made early navigation difficult.

The colonization of the area was barely slowed by the three [earthquakes in
1811 and 1812](/wiki/1812_New_Madrid_earthquake "1812 New Madrid earthquake"),
estimated at approximately 8 on the [Richter magnitude
scale](/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale "Richter magnitude scale"), that were
centered near [New Madrid, Missouri](/wiki/New_Madrid,_Missouri "New Madrid,
Missouri").

### Steamboat
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Steamboat era")]

Main article: [Steamboats of the
Mississippi](/wiki/Steamboats_of_the_Mississippi "Steamboats of the
Mississippi")

Mark Twain's book, _[Life on the Mississippi](/wiki/Life_on_the_Mississippi
"Life on the Mississippi")_ , covered the [steamboat](/wiki/Steamboat
"Steamboat") commerce which took place from 1830 to 1870 on the river before
more modern ships replaced the steamer. The book was published first in serial
form in _[Harper's Weekly](/wiki/Harper%27s_Weekly "Harper's Weekly")_ in
seven parts in 1875. The full version, including a passage from the then
unfinished _[Adventures of Huckleberry
Finn](/wiki/Adventures_of_Huckleberry_Finn "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn")_
and works from other authors, was published by James R. Osgood & Company in
1885.

The first steamboat to travel the full length of the Lower Mississippi from
the Ohio River to New Orleans was the _[New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans_\(steamboat\) "New Orleans \(steamboat\)")_ in
December 1811. Its maiden voyage occurred during the series of [New Madrid
earthquakes](/wiki/1812_New_Madrid_earthquake "1812 New Madrid earthquake") in
1811–12. The Upper Mississippi was treacherous, unpredictable and to make
traveling worse, the area was not properly mapped out or surveyed. Until the
1840s only two trips a year to the Twin Cities landings were made by
steamboats which suggests it was not very profitable.[73]

Steamboat transport remained a viable industry, both in terms of passengers
and freight until the end of the first decade of the 20th century. Among the
several Mississippi River system steamboat companies was the noted [Anchor
Line](/wiki/Anchor_Line_\(riverboat_company\) "Anchor Line \(riverboat
company\)"), which, from 1859 to 1898, operated a luxurious fleet of steamers
between St. Louis and New Orleans.

Italian explorer Giacomo Beltrami, wrote about his journey on the Virginia,
which was the first steam boat to make it to Fort St. Anthony in Minnesota. He
referred to his voyage as a promenade that was once a journey on the
Mississippi. The steamboat era changed the economic and political life of the
Mississippi, as well as the nature of travel itself. The Mississippi was
completely changed by the steamboat era as it transformed into a flourishing
tourists trade.[74]

### Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Civil War")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Battle_of_Vicksburg%2C_Kurz_and_Allison.png/220px-
Battle_of_Vicksburg%2C_Kurz_and_Allison.png)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Vicksburg,_Kurz_and_Allison.png)

[](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Vicksburg,_Kurz_and_Allison.png "Enlarge")

[Battle of Vicksburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg") (ca.
1888)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Mississippi_River_from_Eunice%2C_Arkansas.jpg/220px-
Mississippi_River_from_Eunice%2C_Arkansas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_from_Eunice,_Arkansas.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi_River_from_Eunice,_Arkansas.jpg "Enlarge")

Mississippi River from [Eunice, Arkansas](/wiki/Eunice,_Arkansas "Eunice,
Arkansas"), a ghost town. Eunice was destroyed by gunboats during the Civil
War.

Control of the river was a strategic objective of both sides in the [American
Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"). In 1862
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)")
forces coming down the river successfully cleared Confederate defenses at
[Island Number 10](/wiki/Battle_of_Island_Number_Ten "Battle of Island Number
Ten") and [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"),
while Naval forces coming upriver from the Gulf of Mexico captured [New
Orleans, Louisiana](/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana "New Orleans, Louisiana").
The remaining major Confederate stronghold was on the heights overlooking the
river at [Vicksburg, Mississippi](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg,
Mississippi"), and the Union's [Vicksburg Campaign](/wiki/Vicksburg_Campaign
"Vicksburg Campaign") (December 1862 to July 1863), and the fall of [Port
Hudson](/wiki/Port_Hudson,_Louisiana "Port Hudson, Louisiana"), completed
control of the lower Mississippi River. The Union victory ending the [Siege of
Vicksburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg") on July 4, 1863, was
pivotal to the Union's final victory of the Civil War.

### 20th and 21st
centuries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: 20th and 21st centuries")]

See also: [Great Mississippi Flood of
1927](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_Flood_of_1927 "Great Mississippi Flood of
1927"), [Great Flood of 1951](/wiki/Great_Flood_of_1951 "Great Flood of
1951"), and [Great Mississippi and Missouri Rivers Flood of
1993](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_and_Missouri_Rivers_Flood_of_1993 "Great
Mississippi and Missouri Rivers Flood of 1993")

The "Big Freeze" of 1918–19 blocked river traffic north of Memphis, Tennessee,
preventing transportation of coal from southern Illinois. This resulted in
widespread shortages, high prices, and rationing of coal in January and
February.[75]

In the spring of 1927, the river broke out of its banks in 145 places, during
the [Great Mississippi Flood of 1927](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_Flood_of_1927
"Great Mississippi Flood of 1927") and inundated 27,000 sq mi (70,000 km2) to
a depth of up to 30 feet (9.1 m).

In 1962 and 1963, industrial accidents spilled 3.5 million US gallons
(13,000,000 L) of [soybean oil](/wiki/Soybean_oil "Soybean oil") into the
Mississippi and [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota_River "Minnesota River") rivers.
The oil covered the Mississippi River from St. Paul to Lake Pepin, creating an
ecological disaster and a demand to control [water
pollution](/wiki/Water_pollution "Water pollution").[76]

On October 20, 1976, the automobile ferry, _[MV George
Prince](/wiki/MV_George_Prince_ferry_disaster "MV George Prince ferry
disaster")_ , was struck by a ship traveling upstream as the ferry attempted
to cross from [Destrehan, Louisiana](/wiki/Destrehan,_Louisiana "Destrehan,
Louisiana"), to [Luling, Louisiana](/wiki/Luling,_Louisiana "Luling,
Louisiana"). Seventy-eight passengers and crew died; only eighteen survived
the accident.

In 1988, the water level of the Mississippi fell to 10 feet (3.0 m) below zero
on the Memphis gauge. The remains of wooden-hulled water craft were exposed in
an area of 4.5 acres (18,000 m2) on the bottom of the Mississippi River at
West Memphis, Arkansas. They dated to the late 19th to early 20th centuries.
The State of Arkansas, the Arkansas Archeological Survey, and the Arkansas
Archeological Society responded with a two-month data recovery effort. The
fieldwork received national media attention as good news in the middle of a
drought.[77]

The [Great Flood of
1993](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_and_Missouri_Rivers_Flood_of_1993 "Great
Mississippi and Missouri Rivers Flood of 1993") was another significant flood,
primarily affecting the Mississippi above its confluence with the Ohio River
at Cairo, Illinois.

Two portions of the Mississippi were designated as [American Heritage
Rivers](/wiki/American_Heritage_Rivers "American Heritage Rivers") in 1997:
the lower portion around Louisiana and Tennessee, and the upper portion around
Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota and Missouri. The Nature Conservancy's project
called "America's Rivershed Initiative" announced a 'report card' assessment
of the entire basin in October 2015 and gave the grade of D+. The assessment
noted the aging navigation and flood control infrastructure along with
multiple environmental problems.[78]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Mississippi-River-
Sandbar-Sunset.jpg/220px-Mississippi-River-Sandbar-
Sunset.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mississippi-River-Sandbar-Sunset.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mississippi-River-Sandbar-Sunset.jpg "Enlarge")

Campsite at the river in Arkansas

In 2002, [Slovenian](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia") long-distance swimmer [Martin
Strel](/wiki/Martin_Strel "Martin Strel") swam the entire length of the river,
from Minnesota to Louisiana, over the course of 68 days. In 2005, the Source
to Sea Expedition[79] paddled the Mississippi and [Atchafalaya
Rivers](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") to benefit the Audubon
Society's Upper Mississippi River Campaign.[80][81]

### Future[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Future")]

Geologists believe that the lower Mississippi could take a new course to the
Gulf. Either of two new routes—through the [Atchafalaya
Basin](/wiki/Atchafalaya_Basin "Atchafalaya Basin") or through [Lake
Pontchartrain](/wiki/Lake_Pontchartrain "Lake Pontchartrain")—might become the
Mississippi's main channel if flood-control structures are overtopped or
heavily damaged during a severe flood.[82][83][84][85][86]

Failure of the [Old River Control Structure](/wiki/Old_River_Control_Structure
"Old River Control Structure"), the [Morganza
Spillway](/wiki/Morganza_Spillway "Morganza Spillway"), or nearby levees would
likely re-route the main channel of the Mississippi through
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana")'s [Atchafalaya
Basin](/wiki/Atchafalaya_Basin "Atchafalaya Basin") and down the [Atchafalaya
River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") to reach the Gulf of
Mexico south of [Morgan City](/wiki/Morgan_City,_Louisiana "Morgan City,
Louisiana") in southern Louisiana. This route provides a more direct path to
the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") than the present
Mississippi River channel through [Baton Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge,_Louisiana
"Baton Rouge, Louisiana") and [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans").[84] While the risk of such a diversion is present during any major
flood event, such a change has so far been prevented by active human
intervention involving the construction, maintenance, and operation of various
levees, spillways, and other control structures by the [U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/U.S._Army_Corps_of_Engineers "U.S. Army Corps of Engineers").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Old_River_Control_Structure_Complex.jpg/220px-
Old_River_Control_Structure_Complex.jpg)](/wiki/File:Old_River_Control_Structure_Complex.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Old_River_Control_Structure_Complex.jpg "Enlarge")

The Old River Control Structure complex. View is to the [east-
southeast](/wiki/East-southeast "East-southeast"), looking downriver on the
Mississippi, with the three dams across channels of the [Atchafalaya
River](/wiki/Atchafalaya_River "Atchafalaya River") to the right of the
Mississippi. [Concordia Parish, Louisiana](/wiki/Concordia_Parish,_Louisiana
"Concordia Parish, Louisiana") is in the foreground, on the right, and
[Wilkinson County, Mississippi](/wiki/Wilkinson_County,_Mississippi "Wilkinson
County, Mississippi"), is in the background, across the Mississippi on the
left.

The Old River Control Structure, between the present Mississippi River channel
and the Atchafalaya Basin, sits at the normal water elevation and is
ordinarily used to divert 30% of the Mississippi's flow to the Atchafalaya
River. There is a steep drop here away from the Mississippi's main channel
into the Atchafalaya Basin. If this facility were to fail during a major
flood, there is a strong concern the water would [scour](/wiki/Bridge_scour
"Bridge scour") and erode the river bottom enough to capture the Mississippi's
main channel. The structure was nearly lost during the [1973
flood](/wiki/1973_Mississippi_River_floods "1973 Mississippi River floods"),
but repairs and improvements were made after engineers studied the forces at
play. In particular, the Corps of Engineers made many improvements and
constructed additional facilities for routing water through the vicinity.
These additional facilities give the Corps much more flexibility and potential
flow capacity than they had in 1973, which further reduces the risk of a
catastrophic failure in this area during other major floods, such as that of
[2011](/wiki/2011_Mississippi_River_floods "2011 Mississippi River floods").

Because the Morganza Spillway is slightly higher and well back from the river,
it is normally dry on both sides.[87] Even if it failed at the crest during a
severe flood, the flood waters would have to erode to normal water levels
before the Mississippi could permanently jump channel at this
location.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] During the 2011 floods, the Corps of Engineers
opened the Morganza Spillway to 1/4 of its capacity to allow 150,000 ft3/sec
of water to flood the Morganza and Atchafalaya floodways and continue directly
to the Gulf of Mexico, bypassing Baton Rouge and New Orleans.[88] In addition
to reducing the Mississippi River crest downstream, this diversion reduced the
chances of a channel change by reducing stress on the other elements of the
control system.[89]

Some geologists have noted that the possibility for course change into the
Atchafalaya also exists in the area immediately north of the Old River Control
Structure. Army Corps of Engineers geologist Fred Smith once stated, "The
Mississippi wants to go west. 1973 was a forty-year flood. The big one lies
out there somewhere—when the structures can't release all the floodwaters and
the levee is going to have to give way. That is when the river's going to jump
its banks and try to break through."[90]

Another possible course change for the Mississippi River is a diversion into
[Lake Pontchartrain](/wiki/Lake_Pontchartrain "Lake Pontchartrain") near [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"). This route is controlled by the
[Bonnet Carré Spillway](/wiki/Bonnet_Carr%C3%A9_Spillway "Bonnet Carré
Spillway"), built to reduce flooding in New Orleans. This spillway and an
imperfect natural levee about 4–6 meters (12 to 20 feet) high are all that
prevents the Mississippi from taking a new, shorter course through Lake
Pontchartrain to the Gulf of Mexico.[91] Diversion of the Mississippi's main
channel through Lake Pontchartrain would have consequences similar to an
Atchafalaya diversion, but to a lesser extent, since the present river channel
would remain in use past Baton Rouge and into the New Orleans area.

##
Recreation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Recreation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/MississippiRiverBluffs.jpg/170px-
MississippiRiverBluffs.jpg)](/wiki/File:MississippiRiverBluffs.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MississippiRiverBluffs.jpg "Enlarge")

[Great River Road](/wiki/Great_River_Road "Great River Road") in Wisconsin
near [Lake Pepin](/wiki/Lake_Pepin "Lake Pepin") (2005)

The sport of [water skiing](/wiki/Waterskiing "Waterskiing") was invented on
the river in a wide region between Minnesota and Wisconsin known as [Lake
Pepin](/wiki/Lake_Pepin "Lake Pepin").[92] [Ralph
Samuelson](/wiki/Ralph_Samuelson "Ralph Samuelson") of [Lake City,
Minnesota](/wiki/Lake_City,_Minnesota "Lake City, Minnesota"), created and
refined his skiing technique in late June and early July 1922. He later
performed the first water ski jump in 1925 and was pulled along at 80 mph (130
km/h) by a Curtiss [flying boat](/wiki/Flying_boat "Flying boat") later that
year.[92]

There are seven [National Park Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National
Park Service") sites along the Mississippi River. The [Mississippi National
River and Recreation
Area](/wiki/Mississippi_National_River_and_Recreation_Area "Mississippi
National River and Recreation Area") is the National Park Service site
dedicated to protecting and interpreting the Mississippi River itself. The
other six National Park Service sites along the river are (listed from north
to south):

  * [Effigy Mounds National Monument](/wiki/Effigy_Mounds_National_Monument "Effigy Mounds National Monument")
  * [Jefferson National Expansion Memorial](/wiki/Jefferson_National_Expansion_Memorial "Jefferson National Expansion Memorial") (includes [Gateway Arch](/wiki/Gateway_Arch "Gateway Arch"))
  * [Vicksburg National Military Park](/wiki/Vicksburg_National_Military_Park "Vicksburg National Military Park")
  * [Natchez National Historical Park](/wiki/Natchez_National_Historical_Park "Natchez National Historical Park")
  * [New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park](/wiki/New_Orleans_Jazz_National_Historical_Park "New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park")
  * [Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve](/wiki/Jean_Lafitte_National_Historical_Park_and_Preserve "Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve")

## Ecology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Ecology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f7/Paddlefish_underwater.jpeg/220px-
Paddlefish_underwater.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Paddlefish_underwater.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Paddlefish_underwater.jpeg "Enlarge")

The [American paddlefish](/wiki/American_paddlefish "American paddlefish") is
an ancient [relict](/wiki/Relict_\(biology\) "Relict \(biology\)") from the
Mississippi

The Mississippi basin is home to a highly diverse aquatic [fauna](/wiki/Fauna
"Fauna") and has been called the "mother fauna" of North American fresh
water.[93]

### Fish[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Fish")]

About 375 fish species are known from the Mississippi basin, far exceeding
other North Hemisphere river basin exclusively within temperate/subtropical
regions,[93] except the [Yangtze](/wiki/Yangtze "Yangtze").[94] Within the
Mississippi basin, streams that have their source in the Appalachian and
[Ozark](/wiki/Ozark "Ozark") highlands contain especially many species. Among
the fish species in the basin are numerous [endemics](/wiki/Endemic
"Endemic"), as well as [relicts](/wiki/Relict_\(biology\) "Relict
\(biology\)") such as [paddlefish](/wiki/American_paddlefish "American
paddlefish"), [sturgeon](/wiki/Sturgeon "Sturgeon"), [gar](/wiki/Gar "Gar")
and [bowfin](/wiki/Bowfin "Bowfin").[93]

Because of its size and high species diversity, the Mississippi basin is often
divided into subregions. The Upper Mississippi River alone is home to about
120 fish species, including [walleye](/wiki/Walleye "Walleye"),
[sauger](/wiki/Sauger "Sauger"), [large mouth bass](/wiki/Large_mouth_bass
"Large mouth bass"), [small mouth bass](/wiki/Small_mouth_bass "Small mouth
bass"), [white bass](/wiki/White_bass "White bass"), [northern
pike](/wiki/Northern_pike "Northern pike"), [bluegill](/wiki/Bluegill
"Bluegill"), [crappie](/wiki/Crappie "Crappie"), [channel
catfish](/wiki/Channel_catfish "Channel catfish"), [flathead
catfish](/wiki/Flathead_catfish "Flathead catfish"), [common
shiner](/wiki/Common_shiner "Common shiner"), [freshwater
drum](/wiki/Freshwater_drum "Freshwater drum") and [shovelnose
sturgeon](/wiki/Shovelnose_sturgeon "Shovelnose sturgeon").[95][96]

### Other
fauna[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Other fauna")]

In addition to fish, several species of turtles (such as
[snapping](/wiki/Common_snapping_turtle "Common snapping turtle"),
[musk](/wiki/Sternotherus "Sternotherus"), [mud](/wiki/Kinosternon
"Kinosternon"), [map](/wiki/Graptemys "Graptemys"), [cooter](/wiki/Pseudemys
"Pseudemys"), [painted](/wiki/Painted_turtle "Painted turtle") and
[softshell](/wiki/Apalone "Apalone") turtles), [American
alligator](/wiki/American_alligator "American alligator"), aquatic amphibians
(such as [hellbender](/wiki/Hellbender "Hellbender"),
[mudpuppy](/wiki/Mudpuppy "Mudpuppy"), [three-toed amphiuma](/wiki/Three-
toed_amphiuma "Three-toed amphiuma") and [lesser siren](/wiki/Lesser_siren
"Lesser siren")),[97] and [cambarid](/wiki/Cambaridae "Cambaridae") crayfish
(such as the [red swamp crayfish](/wiki/Red_swamp_crayfish "Red swamp
crayfish")) are native to the Mississippi basin.[98]

### Introduced
species[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Introduced species")]

Numerous [introduced species](/wiki/Introduced_species "Introduced species")
are found in the Mississippi and some of these are
[invasive](/wiki/Invasive_species "Invasive species"). Among the introductions
are fish such as [Asian carp](/wiki/Asian_carp_in_North_America "Asian carp in
North America"), including the [silver carp](/wiki/Silver_carp "Silver carp")
that have become infamous for outcompeting native fish and their potentially
dangerous [jumping behavior](/wiki/Asian_carp_in_North_America#Jumping_ability
"Asian carp in North America"). They have spread throughout much of the basin,
even approaching (but not yet invading) the Great Lakes.[99] The [Minnesota
Department of Natural
Resources](/wiki/Minnesota_Department_of_Natural_Resources "Minnesota
Department of Natural Resources") has designated much of the Mississippi River
in the state as infested waters by the exotic species [zebra
mussels](/wiki/Zebra_mussel "Zebra mussel") and [Eurasian
watermilfoil](/wiki/Eurasian_watermilfoil "Eurasian watermilfoil").[100]

###
Literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Literature")]

  * [William Faulkner](/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner") uses the Mississippi River and Delta as the setting for many hunts throughout his novels. It has been proposed that in Faulkner's famous story, _[The Bear](/wiki/Go_Down,_Moses "Go Down, Moses")_ , young Ike first begins his transformation into a man, thus relinquishing his birthright to land in [Yoknapatawpha County](/wiki/Yoknapatawpha_County "Yoknapatawpha County") through his realizations found within the woods surrounding the Mississippi River.
  * Many of the works of Mark Twain deal with or take place near the Mississippi River. One of his first major works, _[Life on the Mississippi](/wiki/Life_on_the_Mississippi "Life on the Mississippi")_ , is in part a history of the river, in part a memoir of Twain's experiences on the river, and a collection of tales that either take place on or are associated with the river. The river was noted for the number of bandits which called its islands and shores home, including [John Murrell](/wiki/John_Murrell_\(bandit\) "John Murrell \(bandit\)") who was a well-known murderer, horse stealer and slave "re-trader". His notoriety was such that author Twain devoted an entire chapter to him in _Life on the Mississippi_ , and Murrell was rumored to have an island headquarters on the river at Island 37. Twain's most famous work, _[Adventures of Huckleberry Finn](/wiki/Adventures_of_Huckleberry_Finn "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn")_ , is largely a journey down the river. The novel works as an episodic meditation on American culture with the river having multiple different meanings including independence, escape, freedom, and adventure.
  * [Herman Melville](/wiki/Herman_Melville "Herman Melville")'s novel _[The Confidence-Man](/wiki/The_Confidence-Man "The Confidence-Man")_ portrayed a [_Canterbury Tales_](/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales "The Canterbury Tales")-style group of steamboat passengers whose interlocking stories are told as they travel down the Mississippi River. The novel is written both as cultural satire and a metaphysical treatise. Like _Huckleberry Finn_ , it uses the Mississippi River as a metaphor for the larger aspects of American and human identity that unify the otherwise disparate characters. The river's fluidity is reflected by the often shifting personalities and identities of Melville's "confidence man".
  * Much of [Edna Ferber](/wiki/Edna_Ferber "Edna Ferber")'s 1926 novel _[Show Boat](/wiki/Show_Boat_\(novel\) "Show Boat \(novel\)")_ takes place on the Mississippi River. The novel is the basis for the celebrated [1927 musical play](/wiki/Show_Boat "Show Boat") by [Jerome Kern](/wiki/Jerome_Kern "Jerome Kern") and [Oscar Hammerstein II](/wiki/Oscar_Hammerstein_II "Oscar Hammerstein II").

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mississippi_River&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Music")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/On_The_Mississippi.jpg/170px-
On_The_Mississippi.jpg)](/wiki/File:On_The_Mississippi.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:On_The_Mississippi.jpg "Enlarge")

_On The Mississippi_ , music sheet cover for a 1912 song

  * The song "[When the Levee Breaks](/wiki/When_the_Levee_Breaks "When the Levee Breaks")", made famous in the version performed by [Led Zeppelin](/wiki/Led_Zeppelin "Led Zeppelin") on the album _[Led Zeppelin IV](/wiki/Led_Zeppelin_IV "Led Zeppelin IV")_ , was composed by [Memphis Minnie](/wiki/Memphis_Minnie "Memphis Minnie") McCoy in 1929 after the [Great Mississippi Flood of 1927](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_Flood_of_1927 "Great Mississippi Flood of 1927"). Another song about the flood was "Louisiana 1927" by [Randy Newman](/wiki/Randy_Newman "Randy Newman") for the album _Good Old Boys._
  * [Ferde Grofé](/wiki/Ferde_Grof%C3%A9 "Ferde Grofé") composed a set of movements for symphony orchestra entitled "[Mississippi Suite](/wiki/Mississippi_Suite "Mississippi Suite")", based on the lands the river travels through.
  * The stage and movie musical _[Show Boat](/wiki/Show_Boat "Show Boat")_ 's central musical piece is the [spiritual](/wiki/Spirituality "Spirituality")-influenced ballad "[Ol' Man River](/wiki/Ol%27_Man_River "Ol' Man River")". Its composer, [Jerome Kern](/wiki/Jerome_Kern "Jerome Kern"), also composed an orchestral piece entitled "Mark Twain Suite".
  * The musical _[Big River](/wiki/Big_River_\(musical\) "Big River \(musical\)")_ is based on the travels of Huckleberry Finn down the river.
  * The [Johnny Cash](/wiki/Johnny_Cash "Johnny Cash") song "[Big River](/wiki/Big_River_\(Johnny_Cash_song\) "Big River \(Johnny Cash song\)")" is about the Mississippi River, and about drifting the length of the river to pursue a relationship that fails. The places mentioned in the song are [Saint Paul](/wiki/Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "Saint Paul, Minnesota"), [Davenport](/wiki/Davenport,_Iowa "Davenport, Iowa"), [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), [Memphis](/wiki/Memphis "Memphis"), [Baton Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge "Baton Rouge") and [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans").
  * "[Louisiana 1927](/wiki/Louisiana_1927 "Louisiana 1927")" is a 1974 song written and recorded by Randy Newman on the album Good Old Boys. It tells the story of the Great Mississippi River Flood of 1927 which left 700,000 people homeless in Louisiana and Mississippi.
  * Illinois-born singer [Lissie](/wiki/Lissie "Lissie") has a song called _Oh Mississippi_ dedicated to the river.
  * "[Roll On Mississippi](/wiki/Roll_On_Mississippi "Roll On Mississippi")" and "[Mississippi Cotton Picking Delta Town](/wiki/Mississippi_Cotton_Picking_Delta_Town "Mississippi Cotton Picking Delta Town")" are two classics from [Charley Pride](/wiki/Charley_Pride "Charley Pride") that refer to the Mississippi River.
  * The late [Conway Twitty](/wiki/Conway_Twitty "Conway Twitty") and [Loretta Lynn](/wiki/Loretta_Lynn "Loretta Lynn") collaborated on the song "[Louisiana Woman, Mississippi Man](/wiki/Louisiana_Woman,_Mississippi_Man "Louisiana Woman, Mississippi Man")".
  * [Paul Simon](/wiki/Paul_Simon "Paul Simon") mentions the river and the [Mississippi Delta](/wiki/Mississippi_Delta "Mississippi Delta") in his song "[Graceland](/wiki/Graceland_\(song\) "Graceland \(song\)")".
